message: As we begin the New Year, it’s important to take stock of all we’ve accomplished over the last year by working together and supporting our friends, neighbors, and communities. I’ve enjoyed spending time with so many North Dakotans this past year and working for our state – whether it was in the field with farmers talking about the next Farm Bill or bringing together folks in Indian Country to talk about the impacts of childhood trauma. Have a great New Year, and I look forward to working with all of you to make an even better future for our state in 2017.
Talked about the importance of fighting for a strong Farm Bill in 2018 that supports and protects North Dakota farmers with North Dakota Corn Assoication’s Kevin Skunes from Arthur.

Met with UND’s Coordinator for Sexual Respect & Violence Program, Amber Flynn, to discuss its work to protect and educate students and prevent incidents of sexual violence, dating and domestic violence, and stalking.

Meeting one-on-one with nominees, especially for roles that are critical in keeping our country safe, is a needed step in fully considering the president-elect’s nominated cabinet members. I had a productive meeting with General John F. Kelly, the nominee to lead the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, and as I consider his nomination I look forward to learning more about him through his upcoming Senate hearing. As a member of the U.S. Senate Committee on Homeland Security & Governmental Affairs, one of my duties is to oversee DHS and make sure the department is keeping communities strong and safe in North Dakota and beyond. That’s why I pressed General Kelly about border security, including the need for DHS to quickly and carefully review Northern Border security, as my bill that was signed into law last year requires. General Kelly and I also spoke about cybersecurity issues, and I reinforced my concern that DHS needs to make it a priority to implement my RESPONSE Act, which also became law last year, to better prepare our brave first responders.

Met with a top U.S. Customs and Border Patrol official who oversees the agency’s steps to improve the process for hiring federal workers at the Northern Border and make the federal hiring process more efficient – continuing my work to address recruitment and retention challenges. This meeting was an important step as she provided an update on the needed progress at CBP after I pushed on the agency to make the federal hiring process more efficient so we can fill these needed jobs. We can continue to build on this momentum by implementing ideas from a bill I introduced to strengthen CBP’s ability to recruit and retain our nation’s best and brightest to keep our borders and communities strong and safe.

Click below to go to my new online portal where North Dakotans can offer their questions and comments on President-elect Trump’s cabinet nominees. Any president should be able to nominate those who he feels will best serve in his administration. As a member of the U.S. Senate, it’s my duty to consider these nominees for the very important positions they could hold overseeing federal agencies, and learn about them through meetings and congressional hearings that are open to the public. It’s critical for me to hear from North Dakotans and I encourage folks to visit my website to share their comments and offer questions they have to help make sure the nominees are prepared to lead our country.

Tune in today at 9:00amCT/10:00amET for a Senate Subcommittee hearing on a new report about Backpage dot com’s role in facilitating human trafficking and allowing perpetrators to advertise their victims. Countless incidents in North Dakota and across the country have made clear the role the website plays in human trafficking. We can’t let this horrific crime happen in our backyard and to our children. The findings of the report will be an important step to halting the website’s role in enabling sex trafficking online and I hope folks will tune in today.

Today a U.S. Senate subcommittee held a hearing focused on Backpage’s role to facilitate human trafficking. As folks in North Dakota know all too well, human trafficking doesn’t just happen in places like New York City or at a Super Bowl, it happens in places like Watford City and Minot. At the hearing, I had the opportunity to express firsthand my disappointment and anger about the website’s role in exploiting children to the heads of Backpage. We also heard from three brave parents of human trafficking victims about their journey and struggles. Holding Backpage accountable is a small and critical part to combating human trafficking, but if we all work together I know we can conquer this problem and protect our children. http://bit.ly/2j2IGeZ

The safety of North Dakota’s communities is paramount. During the U.S. Senate hearing on President-elect Trump’s nominee to lead the Department of Homeland Security, General John F. Kelly, I stressed the urgency of implementing my bills which were signed into law last month to review security challenges along the Northern Border and provide training and support to our first responders. We also discussed the need to combat human trafficking and address the unique security challenges in rural communities. Through both my meeting with General Kelly and the Senate hearing, it is clear that he is a proven leader who has deep-rooted knowledge of the threats our nation as well as the challenges our servicemembers face in combat and when they return home from service. I will support his nomination and I look forward to working with him to keep our communities strong and safe. Click here to watch the full video: http://bit.ly/2ik4h1S

Scott Pruitt, the nominee to lead the EPA, and I had a solid discussion on how to best support a true all-of-the-above energy strategy. That means supporting fossil fuels, renewable energies, and biofuels – all while reducing emissions to make sure we have clean air and water. I also reinforced the need for a strong Renewable Fuel Standard, sensible regulations on the oil and gas industry and addressing the overreach of rules like the Clean Power Plan and Waters of the U.S. http://bit.ly/2ihzL5g

Voted against a bill that will enable Congress to repeal the health care reform law without having a replacement plan in place – a reckless move that would rip away affordable health coverage from so many North Dakotans who already have it, including those who signed up for Medicaid under the law. I’ve long said there are good pieces of the health reform law and pieces that need to be fixed. Almost three years ago, I proposed many reasonable reforms to the law, and have offered many others since then. It’s well past time to stop politics and do policy – that’s what I’m trying to accomplish. Click here for a fact sheet on how repealing the law would impact North Dakota: http://bit.ly/2jo2EP2

Met with President-elect Trump’s nominee to lead the Office of Management and Budget, Rep. Mick Mulvaney, to stress how critical strong, permanent flood protections are for families in Fargo and Minot. That conversation is important to have with someone who might help set the incoming administration’s federal funding priorities, and I’ll continue to press OMB about the importance of this support.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

At today’s Senate committee hearing on the nomination of Dr. Ben Carson to lead the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Affairs, I reinforced the need for transitional housing services that provide the support for those overcoming abuse of opioids or homelessness, which are important to North Dakota. And we talked about the need to do everything possible to prevent children and other individuals from getting caught in human trafficking. It’s also critical that trauma-informed practices are used to comprehensively address the challenges in rural and low-income communities, including exposure to poverty, crime, abuse, and other adverse experiences. http://bit.ly/2ii60WR

Met with Andy Puzder, the nominee to lead the U.S. Department of Labor, to stress the need to prioritize healthy working families and rural economies in North Dakota by supporting the FAMILY Act to make sure North Dakotans don’t have to choose between their jobs and caring for a loved one. It’s also critical that a new Labor secretary understands the needs of folks who shower after work. It’s our blue-collar and minimum-wage laborers who perform back-breaking work every day, but often lose sleep wondering how they’re going to make ends meet, what happens if they get sick, or how they’re going to save for retirement. Rural Americans need a fighter – for a livable wage, health and retirement protections, and for commonsense workplace leave policies.

When I met with Linda McMahon, the nominee to lead the Small Business Administration, we talked about the importance of supporting small businesses, the women entrepreneurs, and the inventors across North Dakota and rural America that are brimming with talent. She accepted my invitation to visit North Dakota so she can see firsthand the innovative startups and small businesses across our state. It’s my hope that the next SBA Administrator will continue a robust commitment to spurring job growth and promoting long-term economic prosperity in our rural towns, on our reservations, and in the cities between New York and Silicon Valley.

As the U.S. Senate continues to consider President-elect Trump’s nearly 20 cabinet-level nominees, I encourage North Dakotans visit my online portal to share their questions and comments about the nominees. I’m learning more about the nominees through one-on-one meetings with them and congressional hearings that are open to the public, and it’s critical that I also receive feedback from North Dakotans.

Today I spoke with veterans at the North Dakota VFW mid-winter conference in West Fargo. As the daughter of a proud veteran who helped build the VFW in Mantador, my hometown, the North Dakota VFW has a special place in my heart. Veterans strengthen our communities in so many ways, including through VFW participation, service, and leadership. Everything that veterans give back to their communities is a reminder that we owe them and their families a deep debt of gratitude—and part of repaying that debt is living up to our obligations to our veterans when they take off the uniform. That’s why I’ll keep pushing to reform the Choice Program so it works for our veterans, and so they can get care closer to home.

Excited to announce that this year, Alyx Schmitz of Oakes and Ashlen Wright of West Fargo will represent North Dakota at the prestigious U.S. Senate Youth Program. This week-long trip to Washington, D.C. is an opportunity for high school students to see firsthand how the federal government works and the importance of public service. I’m grateful North Dakota will be represented by two outstanding and hard-working students.

Today I had a solid meeting with Vice President-elect Pence about the need for bipartisanship as the new administration soon starts. We talked about the importance of passing a strong Farm Bill in 2018 – which is my top priority in the U.S. Senate – to support farmers and ranchers. We also discussed the need to work together to advance North Dakota’s and the country’s interests. I look forward to working with him and the new administration and maintaining an open dialogue.

Today I joined a group of U.S. Senators to introduce a bipartisan bill that would ensure the federal government and coal operators honor their obligation of lifetime pensions and health benefits to retired miners and their families. Coal miners across the country and workers in North Dakota have helped build our country with their own sweat and labor, and they keep the lights on in homes for families in every one of our states. This bipartisan bill offers a long-term solution that would make sure Congress values hard work and enables these coal miners to get the health care and pensions that worked so hard for – just as all workers deserve. They deserve nothing less and should know that when the government makes a promise to the hard working men and women of this country, it will honor that promise.

Excited for my new role as the lead Democrat on the U.S. Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, & Urban Affairs Subcommittee on Economic Policy. This subcommittee has oversight over a host of issues, including flood insurance and small business lending, so I’ll be able to bring more focus to affordable flood insurance that keeps communities safe when disaster strikes and access to the tools that encourage innovation, investments, and job growth here at home. I’m excited to build bipartisan economic solutions that rural families, small businesses, and entrepreneurs in North Dakota and across the country need to thrive.

Thrilled to announce that the president has appointed the first two members to the Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children. The Commission was created by my bipartisan bill that was signed into law last October and will consist of 11 members specializing in juvenile justice, social work, and mental and physical health. The Commission will address challenges with poverty, abuse, and so much more that Native children and their communities face.

The President-elect’s nominee for Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, and I met to discuss his commitment to a holistic approach to American diplomacy. I’m glad he shares my support for soft power investments that continue to strengthen American ties with strategic partners and treaty allies. Specifically, I pressed Mr. Tillerson on his thoughts on sanctions against Russia and his willingness to hold the country accountable going forward, and I expressed concerns about his close ties to Russia. I also reinforced the need to stay vigilant when it comes to holding Iran to its commitment to never develop nuclear weapons.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

As the top Democrat on the Senate subcommittee that oversees federal regulations, today I helped lead our first hearing of the new Congress focused on how to make sure federal regulations work for small businesses. Small businesses are the fabric of our state, but too often they are at a disadvantage compared to large corporations when it comes to federal regulations. Our focus should be on making regulations better by getting early feedback from impacted small businesses, and helping folks understand how best to comply with regulations that are designed to keep families and communities safe. http://bit.ly/2iXAcFq

Deputy Colt Allery dedicated his life to law enforcement and protecting and serving North Dakotans as a uniformed officer for several different agencies – and we are deeply indebted to him and to his family for his bravery, service, and sacrifice. I send my most heartfelt thoughts and prayers to his family, his friends, his fellow peace officers, and his entire community in Rolette County. North Dakota’s peace officers are the finest in the nation, and Deputy Allery’s bravery in the line of duty exemplifies that commitment to community and our great state. His memory will live on through family and friends he touched, and through a community he so faithfully served.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

North Dakotans know better than anyone how to work together as a team to get the job done. After a long election, our duty now is to come together, just as North Dakotans do every day. That’s what inauguration is about – looking forward, and getting to work for families in North Dakota and across the country. It’s also a sign of the peaceful transfer of power and it shows our support of the democracy that we live in and cherish. As a U.S. Senator, I work every day to make sure all North Dakotans are heard and that rural America has a voice in Congress – and that will continue. And I’ll also serve as a check and balance in the Senate as needed to make sure this Congress and administration are accountable to our state and support our state. We can do better as a nation, and it’s now up to our new president and Congress to pave the way through bipartisanship and results.

Today the U.S. Senate voted to confirm nominees to lead important national security departments and agencies – including General John F. Kelly as Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. I look forward to working with General Kelly in my role on the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee as the department implements my RESPONSE Act and my bill to secure the Northern Border, which are now law, and we work together on other important national security issues. http://bit.ly/2jJ1bpm

The U.S. Department of Housing & Urban Development released a series of reports on the specific barriers Native communities face in obtaining safe, affordable housing. When I brought then-HUD Secretary Castro to Belcourt in 2014, I knew he felt and understood the permeating challenges that contribute to and stem from a lack of reliable housing. This report can help us begin executing strategies that will improve housing conditions, and change outcomes for future generations. bit.ly/2kklri4

Joined a bipartisan majority of the U.S. Senate to confirm the administration’s nominee to lead the CIA, Rep. Mike Pompeo of Kansas. During his U.S. Senate confirmation hearing, Rep. Pompeo expressed an understanding of how vital the agency’s mission is, and how important it is for that mission to be above partisan politics to effectively do its job. Rep. Pompeo demonstrated during his hearing, and in his time in the House of Representatives, that he’s a qualified pick to lead the agency.

Today President Trump signaled a path forward for the potential construction of the Keystone XL pipeline. Building out our country’s energy infrastructure is a key component of achieving an all-of-the-above North American energy strategy and projects that support our energy, economic, and national security. A true-all-of-the-above energy strategy also means supporting projects that advance renewable energy production, which should also be part of any larger energy strategy for the country. http://bit.ly/2jNQCPB

On the floor of the U.S. Senate, I honored the service, sacrifice, and bravery of Deputy Colt Allery of the Rolette County Sheriff’s Department. Growing up in St. John as an enrolled member of the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians, Colt valued his family and his community more than anything. In his passing, all of North Dakota mourns the loss of a young man who bravely put on the uniform and gave everything to keep us safe. Our thoughts and prayers are with those dearest to him—five beautiful young children, his fiancée, the grandparents who raised him, and a community that already misses his constant smile.
Great to see folks from West River Head Start in Washington, D.C. today. Appreciate all they do to put young North Dakotans on a path toward success.

If the new administration wants to support American workers, there are some key steps it needs to take—like standing up for hardworking families’ retirement security and guaranteeing American businesses and workers the federal benefits they’ve earned. A 59-year-old oil rig worker in North Dakota shouldn’t face Social Security cuts that force him to work until he’s 70, and I pushed Rep. Mulvaney about the importance of protecting hardworking Americans from Social Security cuts at his confirmation hearing to lead the U.S. Office of Management and Budget.

Had a great meeting Colonel Rodney Lewis, commander of Grand Forks Air Force Base. We’re working together—and working hard—to leverage Grand Forks’ strengths to attract future missions, support personnel at the base, and discuss the base’s role in protecting the country’s national security. Already, Grand Forks is leading the way in remotely-piloted aircraft, with a Global Hawk mission, an innovative Enhanced Use Lease that continues to attract private industry, and a robust Customs & Border Protection operation—and we need to make that clear to Air Force leadership.
Watch my interview on CNBC’s Squawk Box this morning where I talked about the president’s recent action on energy infrastructure.

At the Senate Committee hearing on the nomination of Linda McMahon to lead the Small Business Administration, I stressed the importance of understanding and addressing the unique needs of young and Native entrepreneurs. When I sat down with Linda McMahon earlier this month, I spoke with her about the need to zero in on small businesses and startups in rural communities, and I’m glad she accepted my invitation to visit North Dakota so she can see their enterprising work firsthand, just as her predecessor did. http://bit.ly/2kxW0tr

I’m excited to announce that the post office in Halliday will reopen on February 1. In close-knit rural towns like Halliday, even a temporary closure of the local post office can mean severe disruptions for families trying to stay in touch or businesses working to stay on track. When I heard about the post office closing in Halliday, I sprang to action – calling on the U.S. Postmaster General for immediate results to make sure the community knew how to access their mail services as efficiently as possible during the closure. Nearly every day since, my staff on the ground in Dickinson and I worked to bring about a permanent solution – and that’s exactly what will happen on February 1 when the Halliday post office is set to reopen.

Joined folks at the ND American Legion winter conference to thank veterans for their service and talk about my commitment to making sure they get the high quality health care they’ve earned. After all that veterans have done to keep us safe and improve their communities, it’s critical that we live up to our obligations to them once they come home. To accomplish that goal, I’ve pushed VA to fix the Choice Program for North Dakota veterans by giving the Fargo VA more scheduling authority—and I’ll keep pushing for stronger reforms to this program so it works for our veterans, and so they can get care closer to home.

I cannot support Betsy DeVos to serve as the secretary of the U.S. Department of Education. After watching the U.S. Senate hearing on Ms. DeVos’ nomination, it was clear that she doesn’t understand the importance of public schools – highlighting her preference for private schools and her work to accomplish that goal by taking public funds away from public schools. She showed her severe lack of knowledge about rural public schools, which represent about one-third of public schools nationwide. And she doesn’t have a grasp of basic education policy or laws supporting students with disabilities, yet she wants to run the federal agency overseeing the education of our kids. Simply, we need an education secretary who puts students first and will work to strengthen public school education, not someone who would privatize it as Betsy DeVos would.

I cannot support Betsy DeVos to serve as secretary of the U.S. Department of Education. Nearly 1,400 North Dakotans reached out to me about DeVos’ nomination and 95% of them opposed having her be U.S Education Secretary.  I’m the product of a good public school education – so are my six brothers and sisters, and my two kids. In North Dakota and across rural America, a public school education backed up by hardworking teachers is what enables kids to get the education they deserve – and I see the benefits of it for kids over and over again in our state. Taking away those public schools is not an option. She showed her severe lack of knowledge about rural public schools, which represent about one-third of public schools nationwide. And she doesn’t have a grasp of basic education policy or laws supporting students with disabilities, yet she wants to run the federal agency overseeing the education of our kids. Below are some of the comments from North Dakotans.

This month when I spoke with a mother whose young daughter was terrorized on a near daily basis after being trafficked for sex, I asked her what she thought needed to change going forward. Her answer was simple – health care professionals need the training and the tools to recognize and protect victims of sex trafficking. Nearly one-third of women trafficked in America saw a health care professional while still held captive. Today, Senator Collins and I are reintroducing our bipartisan bill to make sure health providers – sometimes some of the only people victims interact with without their trafficker in the room – can identify and help victims of sex trafficking. http://bit.ly/2kMLAD8

Today I reintroduced a bipartisan bill with Republican Senator Susan Collins from Maine to make sure health providers can identify and help victims of sex trafficking. Our nation recognizes Human Trafficking Awareness this month – and by training health professionals to spot potential victims – we can expand awareness in the medical community so they are prepared to intervene and have a clear process on handling the situation. By building on the success of pilot training programs of about 60 doctors, nurses and others in Williston and New Town, we can strengthen our community and nationwide network that unmasks and effectively combats human trafficking, protects victims, and prevents these crimes from proliferating in our towns. http://bit.ly/2kMLAD8
Archbishop of Chicago, Blase J. Cupich, said this the president’s ban on refugees is “contrary to both Catholic and American values.”
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Check out the first episode of my new podcast, “The Hotdish.” On the heels of Human Trafficking Awareness Month in January, I interviewed anti-human trafficking leader Cindy McCain and award-winning WDAY-TV reporter Kevin Wallevand—who has covered human trafficking in North Dakota—to talk about the issue at the local, national, and international level. Podcasts are a fantastic way to reach North Dakotans and explore complicated challenges like human trafficking—challenges that take time to understand and grapple with. When I joined the U.S. Senate four years ago, trafficking was barely on the radar of many in Congress. But that’s changed dramatically, thanks in part to folks like Cindy McCain and Kevin Wallevand. http://bit.ly/2jE9UFs

Today I voted with a bipartisan majority of the U.S. Senate to confirm Rex Tillerson as Secretary of State. Striking a delicate balance between tough, smart national security strategies and pragmatic diplomacy requires a steady hand – and it’s no easy task. It’s critical that any Secretary of State possess the discipline – in the face of the current terrain of difficult relations with adversaries and even allies across the globe – to fully commit to policies that support our country and allies, keep our communities safe, and help spur job growth here at home. I’ve known Mr. Tillerson for a long time and when we met in my office recently I was blunt about my concerns with his ability to assert that discipline given his ties to Russia and the new Administration’s talk of loosening sanctions on the country. While I’ll continue to closely monitor those ties and reinforce the need to stay vigilant on Russia, I look forward to working with Mr. Tillerson on our shared support for soft power investments that reinforce America’s ties with strategic partners and treaty allies and to bolstering America’s proactive approach to diplomatic relations.

We need tough, smart national security strategies that keep Americans safe, but national security experts and leaders – like former director of the CIA under George W. Bush, General Hayden – say the president’s ban on refugees and requirement of a religious test could make America less safe. These actions hurt us in the war against ISIS. They isolate Muslims living in the U.S. who help root out potential terrorists. And they play into the hands of ISIS by confirming the lie terrorists tell their recruits: that America is waging a war on Islam. Because of the president’s actions, the war against ISIS is now tougher.

Today the U.S. Senate voted to undo a rule that made no sense for North Dakota’s lignite coal industry—an industry that supports jobs and rural communities, and powers homes across our state. The Stream Protection Rule was intended to curb runoff and other issues in Appalachia, but it failed to take into account North Dakota’s unique geography and mining practices. North Dakota already leads the nation in reclamation, and this one-size-fits-all rule would have done real harm. Going forward, North Dakota needs federal policies that boost our diverse energy mix so we can continue to create jobs and generate affordable, reliable power.

Watch live while on the floor of the U.S. Senate as I urge my colleagues to do what’s right for our students and public school education system by voting no on Betsy DeVos to lead the U.S. Department of Education.

The President’s ban on refugees and requirement of a religious test puts Americans’ safety at risk. The ban hurts us in the war against ISIS. It isolates Muslims living in the U.S. who help root out potential terrorists. It hurts those from countries like Iraq and Syria who have served as translators, bodyguards, and informants and provided critical information and services to support American operations in their countries. It also confirms the lie terrorists tell their recruits: that America is waging a war on Islam.

2016 was a busy year in the U.S. Senate. I spent a lot of time traveling the state to meet and work with so many wonderful North Dakotans to make our state better. In Washington, my bills to better support first responders, create a Commission on Native Children, and strengthen the Northern Border were all signed into law. I also successfully pushed for a new Vet Center in Grand Forks to better serve those who have given so much to our country, and helped secure critical federal funding for flood protection in the Red River Valley and Minot regions.

Honored to receive the Wheat Advocate award from the North Dakota Grain Growers Association this week. Agriculture is and always will be woven into our state’s fabric – it’s a critical part of our families, communities, and economy. I look forward to continuing to work with North Dakota farmers and ranchers to make sure we have a strong Farm Bill in 2018 that helps North Dakota’s agriculture industry continue to feed the world.
“Of Trump's Cabinet nominees, DeVos is among the least qualified for the intended job because of her uninformed and ideologically skewed views of public education.” http://bit.ly/2kvdcz4

By working across the aisle in the U.S. Senate and side-by-side with North Dakotans across the state, we were able to accomplish a great deal in 2016 to make our state safer and our communities stronger. Check out this video to see my top highlights from last year – including three of my bipartisan bills being signed into law, a new Vet Center in Grand Forks, and federal funding for flood protection around Fargo and Minot.

On the first episode of my new podcast, “The Hotdish,” I talked with anti-human trafficking leader, Cindy McCain, and award-winning WDAY-TV reporter, Kevin Wallevand, about combating human trafficking at the local, national, and international levels. Check it out on my website or Soundcloud. http://bit.ly/2jE9UFs

Read this editorial in the Williston Herald on why Betsy DeVos is not the right person to lead the U.S. Department of Education. Her history of favoring private and charter schools over public schools puts majority of North Dakota public schools in jeopardy. She doesn’t have the experience or knowledge for the highest education job in the country – we can find someone much better. bit.ly/2kF773k

Led a bipartisan group of 17 Senators to introduce a resolution designating this week as National Tribal Colleges and Universities Week. It’s part of my mission in the U.S. Senate to help tribal colleges and universities pave a path toward a better future for Native kids. Last fall, the first bill I introduced as a U.S. senator became law, which will help address the complex struggles Native youth face. Building a better country for Native children so they can realize their full potential is not easy, but when we are united in support of tribal educators and in the fight to support the well-being of Native young people, we can change outcomes.

At today’s meeting with former Governor Sonny Perdue, the nominee to lead the U.S. Department of Agriculture, I highlighted my bipartisan bill I reintroduced that would support farmers and American jobs by lifting restrictions on U.S. agricultural exports to Cuba. My bill would address the biggest barrier North Dakota farmers face as they seek access to Cuba—a market with high demand for the state’s crops—by lifting the ban on private banks and companies offering credit for agricultural exports to Cuba. North Dakota is the ninth largest agriculture exporting state in the U.S., with about $4.1 billion in commodities sold abroad each year. In addition, North Dakota’s agricultural exports support about 27,000 American jobs. http://bit.ly/2kFJsjq

Public school education is personal for me and so many North Dakotans. It opened up opportunities for us that changed our lives and helped us succeed. And it’s how a daughter of a school cook and janitor and seasonal construction worker can become a member of the U.S. Senate. As the proud product of a public school education and after hearing concerns from thousands of North Dakotans, I cannot support Betsy DeVos to lead the U.S. Department of Education. She is unqualified and lacks the basic knowledge needed for the top education job in our country. http://bit.ly/2lcr0iQ

Met with Robert Lighthizer, the administration’s nominee for U.S. Trade Representative, to stress the critical role the USTR plays in making sure North Dakota farmers and ranchers get a fair shake in international trade—and that it’s critical for their bottom line and for supporting good American jobs. Trade is vital for North Dakota, especially for our agricultural producers, so I reinforced to him that any USTR needs to push for good trade agreements that level the playing field for producers, while also holding other countries accountable when they cheat on trade deals.

Leading discussion on leadership with my good friend and global anti-human trafficking advocate, Cindy McCain, at the McCain Institute’s Global Leadership Symposium in Washington, D.C. today. Cindy and I will talk about how we got to where we are today, and what drew us to become fierce advocates in the fight against human trafficking.

Today I voted against confirming Betsy DeVos to lead public schools across rural communities like mine for one very simple reason: Our kids deserve better. During her Senate hearing, Ms. DeVos could not deliver responses to basic education policy questions, or commit to supporting the future of public education. Her refusal and lack of awareness of laws on the books protecting every students’ access to a quality education – including for students with disabilities – signaled a level of disregard for the sacred opportunity of public education. Grateful to have a good friend like Senator Cory Booker from New Jersey to fight for public school education and stand up for children with me in the U.S. Senate.

Following up from the derailment of a crude oil train near Casselton in 2013, the National Transportation Safety Board voted today to recommend a study on the number of buffer cars that should be required between a locomotive and tank cars. Even before this report was finished, I’ve been fighting to make sure our communities and first responders have the tools they need to stay safe. I’ve pushed for strong rules on oil train cars, and just last year I successfully got my bipartisan RESPONSE Act to improve first responder preparedness signed into law. Now that it’s been finalized, this report will help us guarantee our communities and first responders are stronger and safer going forward.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

I will vote against Senator Jeff Sessions to serve as U.S. Attorney General. I respect Jeff Sessions as a colleague and for his distinguished service in the U.S. Senate. But the job of U.S. Attorney General, serving as the nation’s chief law enforcement officer, is about how a person will handle this massive responsibility. I have serious concerns about Senator Sessions’ opposition to landmark legislation in 2013 that protects victims of domestic violence, including protections I advocated for Native American women. He has pushed back against voting rights throughout his career. During the 24th anniversary of the Family and Medical Leave Act, I’m proud to help reintroduce a commonsense bill that would build on that policy by providing paid family and medical leave. Making sure both families and small businesses have the certainty they need to fully dedicate themselves to their work and their families isn’t just a core North Dakota value, it’s good commonsense for both hardworking employees and businesses’ bottom lines. Today I met with Judge Neil Gorsuch, the nominee to fill the vacancy on the U.S. Supreme Court. One of the most important roles of a U.S. senator is to vet nominees to fill vacancies on the U.S. Supreme Court through meetings and Senate hearings, and I take that job very seriously. Unfortunately, Senate Republicans broke tradition and historical precedent in refusing to give Judge Merrick Garland the full and fair consideration he deserved when he was nominated to serve on the Supreme Court, forcing his nomination to languish for almost 300 days – by far the longest that a Supreme Court nomination has been held open. Unlike my colleagues, I believe my duty of advice and consent in these matters remains the same regardless of which party is in the White House – it is our job as U.S. Senators to perform this function and not play politics. That’s why I met with Judge Gorsuch today, and I appreciate him taking the time to come by my office. We had a thorough conversation about the importance of the rule of law and of a judiciary that is independent of the executive and legislative branches of government. We also talked about Indian law and treaties, fixing our criminal justice system, and empathy on the bench—a fundamental trait when the poor and underprivileged in North Dakota and beyond don’t have the same access to the courts as those who are better off.

Working families are the backbone of North Dakota communities and our state’s economy – and they shouldn’t face the impossible choice of keeping a job which pays the rent and caring for their loved ones. I’m proud to help reintroduce a commonsense bill, the FAMILY Act, that would better support working families and level the playing field for small business by providing federal paid leave. For only an average of $1.50 a week – which is about the same as a cup of coffee – the FAMILY Act would provide 12 weeks of paid medical and family leave. Proud to receive the “Legislator of the Year” award from Agricultural Retailers Association. For over a year, I fought with North Dakota agricultural retailers to stop a harmful OSHA standard that would have put across-the-board restrictions on agricultural retailers that sell anhydrous ammonia, a common fertilizer. Had the rule gone into effect, it would have forced anhydrous ammonia retailers to shut down due to excessive compliance costs, forcing North Dakota farmers to pay more and travel greater distances with anhydrous—and that certainly wouldn’t have increased safety. Going forward, I’ll keep fighting wrongheaded federal policies to make sure farmers, ranchers, and the businesses that support them continue to thrive.

After the congressional committees do their investigations, if it is determined more issues need to be looked into, then our legislation supporting an independent commission could be a next step. The American people deserve answers so they can judge Russia’s interference for themselves, and thorough investigations are the best way to get those answers. http://bit.ly/2lQDPN2

North Dakota needs true all-of-the-above energy policies, commonsense protections for our air and water, and smart management of federal and Indian lands. After evaluating former Texas Governor Rick Perry to lead the Energy Department, Congressman Ryan Zinke of Montana to lead the Interior Department, and Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt to lead the EPA through meetings, reviewing their records, and at their respective U.S. Senate committee hearings, I determined that each of them would be open to working on issues important to North Dakota in a pragmatic and fair way. Once confirmed, I’ll hold them accountable to make sure they carry out each agency’s mission in a way that does actually work for North Dakota—and that continues to protect our air and water, tribal lands and sovereignty, and all forms of energy.   Once Mr. Pruitt is confirmed to lead EPA, I’ll work to make sure EPA focuses on smart regulation and works with states and local communities to address issues like the unworkable Waters of the U.S. rule and the punitive final Clean Power Plan rules. Though I have concerns about his commitment to a comprehensive energy strategy that includes renewables and his commitment to reduce emissions to protect our air and water, I’ll work to hold Pruitt accountable and make sure North Dakota’s interests are heard—just as I held the previous EPA administrator accountable. I’ll also push Pruitt to meet statutory requirements under the Renewable Fuel Standard, which I pressed him on during a meeting last month given how important a robust RFS is for North Dakota farmers and biofuels workers. At the Department of Energy, I’ll work with Mr. Perry to advance an all-of-the-above energy strategy with a focus on building a viable future for coal through increased investment and emphasis on clean coal technology. Mr. Zinke already has an understanding of federal and tribal land issues having represented Montana, and I’ll work with him to streamline oil and gas permitting on federal lands, increase energy development opportunities in Indian Country, and to maintain good relationships with tribes, which is crucial for Interior.

Tonight, the president called for the country to unite, and I couldn’t agree more. Our country works best when we work together on real results for the American people. It’s past time to put politics aside and work on policy. It was an aspirational speech and there were a lot of ideas in it, but the devil is in the details. The president will now need to flesh out how his policies will actually work and provide specifics about how to accomplish them. It was encouraging to see Republicans stand up for proposals that they haven’t traditionally been supportive of, including paid family leave – which I have a bill on – and an infrastructure package – which we recently introduced that will support the whole country including rural America. I expressed concerns when our previous president didn’t talk about rural America, and I had the same concerns with this speech. There wasn’t a mention of rural America, a farm bill, or agriculture workers, and these should be focuses for any leader of our country.  The president did talk about supporting American workers and I hope we can work together to give workers and retirees the support they need to get and keep jobs to support their families, and to live with dignity with secure retirements and pensions. He talked about expanding our nation’s energy infrastructure, which I’ve long been a proponent of, and supporting American-made products. We also must make sure that any tax reform has to work for families just trying to put food on the table.  I intend to work with the president to get results for North Dakota, and I’ll also serve as a check and balance in the U.S. Senate as needed to hold this Congress and administration accountable to our state. Now it’s time to pave the way forward by working together and I hope the president follows his own speech about working in a bipartisan way.

Today, Johnny Smith and Eddie Embry, two coal miners from Kentucky, joined me on KFGO radio to talk about why it’s so critical that Congress works to make sure these coal miners with the United Mine Workers of America get the health care and pensions they earned.   Johnny told us about his brother, Kenny, who is 65 years old and from Centertown, KY. Kenny worked in the mines for 15 years before he fell down a slope in a mine and hurt his back. He has since been on disability. Kenny now also has serious heart problems and had a heart pump put in several years ago until he gets a heart transplant. But years later, he’s still waiting for that heart transplant. He has now had four heart pumps, including one that got infected. Kenny has been in the hospital for 250 days in the past year and had three major surgeries. Without a fix to the pensions and health care for UMWA workers, Kenny’s health insurance will go away in April. Without health insurance, he would not still be with us today. But what happens to him in April?  When miners like Kenny took these labor intensive jobs that keep all of our lights on, they were promised health care to support themselves and pensions to support their families in the long-term. Except, suddenly everything changed for them. Their pensions and health care have been ripped out from under them even though coal companies committed this money to the UMWA and its workers during bankruptcy proceedings. At the very end of last year, Congress funded a temporary extension of miners’ health benefits, but it expires in April. If Congress doesn’t act, the health care and pensions for thousands of UMWA miners, including many in Kentucky and West Virginia, will go away in April. Congress must pass the Miners Protection Act to give these miners the support they earned and deserve.  When I think of these miners, I also think of the thousands of workers and retirees across the country – including 2,000 families in North Dakota and 400,000 retirees – who could have their health care and pensions ripped away from the Central States Pension Fund. I’ve been to the Teamsters union halls in North Dakota. I’ve heard the stories of these workers and retirees. I’ve seen their tears and pain.   All of these workers and retirees – whether with the UMWA or Teamsters -- did everything right. We need to reward their hard work by making sure families’ retirement savings are secure and will be there when they most need it.

As we begin #WomensHistoryMonth, it’s a reminder that there are so many smart, strong women who have helped shape, inspire, and guide me throughout my life – as is the case for so many other women –  but none has had a bigger impact on me than my mother. When I was growing up, she had seven kids in nine years – and if you’ve met any of my brothers and sisters or me, you know we aren’t really a quiet bunch. My mom worked hard not only to raise us, but to make sure we supported our neighbors and community, knew that our dreams should always aim for the stars, and understood that our voices matter and are meant to be heard.   My mom won’t be in any history books, but like so many mothers and hardworking women, her generosity, compassion, patience, and selflessness will impact her family and friends for a lifetime.   During #WomensHistoryMonth and throughout the year, it’s important we acknowledge that our success comes only because we started on the shoulders of the giants who came before us. Both icons in American history like Susan B. Anthony and Eleanor Roosevelt, and our moms, grandmothers, and sisters – strong, smart women who inspire us every day. We must also remain diligent in the fight to stand up for women – both in the workplace and at home. We’ve come a long way, but there’s still much more work we need to do.   Let’s stand together this month and every month to support the women in our lives, encourage girls to be strong and take charge, and continue striving for progress for women everywhere.

Today is the four year anniversary of the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act – the first bill I co-sponsored when I joined the U.S. Senate. As North Dakota’s Attorney General in the 1990s, I implemented VAWA at the state level and saw firsthand the life-changing impact it had on the lives of so many North Dakota women and families. This law told women who were victims of domestic and sexual abuse that they were no longer alone, and let abusers know that we were coming after them. When people ask me why Washington’s so broken, I tell them there’s too much undisclosed money, and we need to get into the sunshine here. That’s why I joined Senator Jon Tester from Montana to push for the SUN Act – a bill that would help shine a light on dark money in politics. Right now, tax-exempt non-profits can take money from wealthy individuals who want to remain anonymous, bundle it together, and use it to influence North Dakotans’ opinions with TV or radio ads, direct mail, or more. Our bill would help guarantee the public knows who's trying to influence elections, so our government is responsive to the people -- not special interests. Read more in this Dickinson Press article about how this bill would make sure North Dakotans know who is behind these year-round political ads.

Some increases to defense spending are needed, but it’s irrational to pay for those increases by crippling programs that strengthen American families and rural communities. The president's proposed budget would seriously hurt North Dakota and rural America. The budget would slash $4.7 billion from the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s budget, and reduce staffing at USDA field offices that North Dakota farmers and ranchers rely on. It entirely cuts rural development programs that guarantee clean water for families and businesses in North Dakota—programs that provided our state with $37 million in federal funding in the last two years alone. It would eliminate a program that provided $22 million just last year to help low-income North Dakota families, seniors, and folks in Indian Country heat their homes this winter. By cutting $1 billion in funding for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, this budget would jeopardize flood protections in North Dakota that are critical to keeping our communities strong and safe. The budget would also end a federal program that guarantees affordable air travel in rural communities, which helped Devils Lake’s airport board a record-breaking 6,290 passengers last year. Each year, that program invests $4.2 million in Dickinson’s airport, $4 million in Devils Lake’s, and $2.8 million in Jamestown’s, helping keep rural economies vibrant and connected.   This budget is a blueprint of the administration’s priorities, but it unfortunately leaves behind North Dakota and rural communities across this country. Ultimately, it's Congress’ job to set spending priorities and fund the government—and I’ll fight to make sure an even-handed approach wins out, so programs North Dakota businesses and families rely on don’t face senseless cuts.

Meals on Wheels makes a difference in the lives of thousands of North Dakota seniors who are home-bound. And it doesn’t just provide healthy meals—it also makes sure folks in our communities are checking in on our older neighbors who might need a helping hand. In North Dakota, we know that community means taking care of one another, and programs like this can help. But the president’s budget would slash federal funding available to Meals on Wheels in North Dakota and across the country. To protect our seniors, I’ll fight to preserve this vital program.

North Dakota can also play a key role maintaining U.S. security as it relates to Russia. Tough talk about infrastructure and diverse energy needs is easy – but that talk needs to be followed by real actions. Now that the Administration has cleared this hurdle for construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, TransCanada can continue its work to secure the remaining pieces necessary to begin construction. While there are still several steps before construction can begin, today’s announcement is important to renewing the United States’ commitment toward mutually beneficial energy solutions with Canada. It’s my hope that we can roll up our up our sleeves and take the real, pragmatic steps our country needs to become energy secure. For years I’ve been working from the middle out to persuade cooler heads to prevail on this project in the U.S. Senate, and I’m ready to get to work.

This week, I’ll introduce a bill that would help identify best practices to reduce the impacts of trauma to help make sure children and families no longer suffer in silence. Trauma is the negative impact that severely stressful events, such as witnessing violence, exposure to unaddressed mental health issues, or abuse can have on a child that can lead to lifelong harmful effects. Exposure to trauma is a reality for far too many children and families – particularly those in Native communities. Now that the science of trauma is clear, we can and must to do more to mitigate its long-term impacts. My bill aims to do that by making sure folks are supported by a network of informed law enforcement officers, health care workers, and tribal and education specialists who recognize and treat exposure to trauma as the clinical condition that it is. Learn more about trauma and its long-term health impacts here: http://bit.ly/2o39ZJ6

Earlier this week at Lutheran Social Services’ Building Bridges conference, the organization recognized 30 first-generation immigrant and refugee students from Fargo whose stories were included in the new book, “Green Card Youth Voices: Immigration Stories from a Fargo High School.” The purpose is to show in a very personal way the growing diversity that immigration and our refugee population brings to North Dakota by sharing the stories of these students who now live in Fargo – and many of whom overcame great obstacles like famine and war just to get to our state for better lives. North Dakota must be a place that is open to everyone, and that makes our community stronger. While I sadly wasn’t able to be at the conference in person, I sent them this video message to make sure those students who courageously shared their stories know how proud I am of them and that I will always be their champion -- as well as a champion for our entire state -- in North Dakota and in Washington.

As I said after Judge Garland was nominated and I’ve continued to say since Judge Gorsuch was nominated, one of the most important roles of a U.S. senator is to vet nominees to fill vacancies on the U.S. Supreme Court and I take that job very seriously. After doing my due diligence by meeting with Judge Gorsuch and reviewing his record and testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, I’ve decided to vote in favor of his confirmation. He has a record as a balanced, meticulous, and well respected jurist who understands the rule of law. He has unique and critical experience with tribal sovereignty, Indian law, and public lands issues in the west, and has received the endorsement of numerous tribes and major Native American organizations. During our meeting and at his hearing, he reinforced the importance of a judiciary that remains independent of the executive and legislative branches of government – and that acts as a proper check and balance on the other two branches of government. I expect him to follow through on that critical tenet.  This vote does not diminish how disturbed I am by what Republicans did to Judge Garland. Senate Republicans played politics at its worst with an honorable, deeply qualified jurist – arguably the most well qualified nominee in modern history – who had long been supported by Republican and Democratic senators for his unmatched experience. His reward: Republicans refused to give him the fair consideration he deserved – not even a hearing – and his nomination was held open for almost 300 days – by far the longest for a Supreme Court nomination. But I was taught that two wrongs don’t make a right. There isn’t a perfect judge. Regardless of which party is in the White House, the U.S. Supreme Court should be above politics.

In Grand Forks, the American Dream Program has used federal funding through the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program to help over 500 working families purchase their first home. The president’s budget would cut CDBG funding and make it much more difficult or impossible for organizations like the American Dream Program to help folks in the community. Owning a home is a point of pride for many folks, but sometimes they need an extra boost to get there. I’ll fight to make sure Congress approves a budget that uses an even-handed approach and doesn’t cut programs that helps North Dakotans move forward and invests in our communities.

Community Service Block Grants (CSBG) has 7 agencies across North Dakota that provided emergency assistance to nearly 64,000 low-income North Dakotans from 2014 to 2016. Emergency assistance includes food baskets, rental assistance, rent deposit, urgent transportation, and more. The president’s budget would eliminate CSBG – leaving behind the thousands of North Dakotans who relied on its support to get by during difficult times. We all know that life can throw curve balls and you can’t always plan ahead. And as North Dakotans, when our neighbors are going through a tough time, we do what we can to be there for them. These federal funds are important to so many folks, and I’ll work to make sure this program that folks rely on doesn’t see senseless cuts.

Reintroduced my bipartisan bill with Republican U.S. Senator Dan Sullivan that would increase access to and promote pro-bono legal services for victims of domestic violence. By making sure domestic violence victims know what legal services are available to them and have access to those services, our bipartisan bill seeks to help end the cycle of violence that imprisons so many across this country. As former Attorneys General, Senator Sullivan and I both understand how the lack of access to legal services can prevent survivors from finding the assistance necessary to stop the cycle of abuse and escape their abuser.

During my meeting with Alexander Acosta, the nominee to lead the U.S. Department of Labor, I reinforced the need to support working families by making sure they get paid family and medical leave to care for loved ones without having to sacrifice their jobs; receive a fair, livable wage; and can count on the retirement security they earned. We also talked about how the president’s budget would slash critical resources to help train workers in rural communities, like Job Corps centers in towns like Minot. We need labor policies and a Labor Secretary that stands up for the folks who shower after work – those whose sweat and labor continue to keep our country strong – and they will continue to be my focus.

Joined 45 other U.S. Senators to call on President Trump to veto recently passed legislation from Congress that would undo important privacy protections. This bill would allow the company folks pay to get internet service to have access to their private information and sell it without their knowledge or approval. If a parent is looking into medical treatment online for a sick child, that information could be sold. If a business owner is looking into new contracts or services online, that information could be sold. If a worker is looking online for a new job, that information could be sold. And internet service providers are very different from sites like Google and Facebook. Search engines and social networks can only see what consumers do on their specific sites – not anything consumers do on the internet, which is what internet search providers can see. In many parts of North Dakota and other rural areas across the country, consumers have access to only one internet service provider, so they don’t even have a choice of which provider sees their information. North Dakotans value their privacy – as should every American – but this legislation takes away that fundamental right, and instead, sells it to the highest bidder.

This Vet Center isn’t just a place to receive valuable services, it’s a home base for our vets to heal, connect with their roots, and establish strong support systems.

The president’s budget would eliminate the Economic Development Administration (EDA) and the federal grants that it administers. The EDA promotes innovation and competitiveness at the state and local level through strategic federal investments. Since 2009, North Dakota has received more than $34 million in investments from the EDA, these investments have spurred more than $478 million in private investments in North Dakota, and have created nearly 1,300 jobs across the state. This program is the perfect example of one that strengthens rural communities through public-private partnerships, and it is irrational to pull the rug out from under towns and regions who use this federal funding to support their communities.

Across the country, up to two-thirds of the 58 percent of workers with access to a retirement savings account are not saving nearly enough to cover the costs of retirement. We owe it to these men and women to invest in workers throughout their careers and after by strengthening our retirement system, including pension funds, particularly when automation is replacing more jobs. http://bit.ly/2oJO369

It’s great news for our veterans and for us as we seek to fulfill the promises we made to the men and women who have served that Congress passed the bipartisan bill I helped introduce to extend and reform the Choice Program. After all they have given to keep us safe, it’s unacceptable to ask our veterans to drive hours to get the x-rays and cancer treatments they need – that’s why I helped pass this bill. The last critical step before we can guarantee veterans can get care in their communities is for the president to sign the bill into law.

In my home state of North Dakota, about 41 percent of private sector employees – that’s roughly 112,000 workers – work for an employer that does not offer a retirement plan.  These are the truck drivers, the sales clerks and farmers that are working hard to make ends meet, put their kids through college, cover healthcare costs and provide a better life for their children.  We owe it to hard working men and women to invest in workers throughout their careers and after by strengthening our retirement system  That’s why I helped lead a Senate subcommittee hearing focused on addressing the vulnerabilities and struggles rural and working American families have in saving and preparing for retirement and how we can better give them the tools they need to have a financial secure future. Watch more from the hearing here: http://bit.ly/2oJO369

All of us saw the horrific, heart wrenching images of innocent men, women, and children in Syria killed and wounded from a chemical weapons attack by its own government, which was a flagrant violation of the Chemical Weapons Convention let alone a moral atrocity. Such senseless and brutal attacks by Bashar al-Assad and his government are a threat to America’s security and our strategic interests in the region, and to innocent Syrians. These actions cannot be tolerated and they deserve a response. Any use of military force is a serious act, and we need to be very careful whenever we escalate our military involvement abroad.   It’s now up to the president to make clear to the American people and to Congress what his long-term plan is in Syria, how he will coordinate with our allies to implement that plan, and how he will secure the safety of American servicemembers in the region involved in the fight against ISIS. The situation in Syria remains volatile and complex, and the United States must also carefully weigh the best options for advancing our interests, which include stabilizing the devastating humanitarian crisis in Syria and the refugee crisis that has resulted from it.

Great news that my bipartisan bill to help encourage and boost investments in small businesses and startups passed in the U.S. House of Representatives with strong bipartisan support. Too often, rules are written without rural American in mind, but by raising the ceiling of accredited investors venture capital funds can acquire from 100 to 250 before SEC registration is required, we would level the playing field startups in North Dakota and rural America.

North Dakota has a reputation for producing cutting-edge research and technology, especially related to energy. The president’s budget would slash the Office of Science’s budget by 20% and pull back on critical investments that help North Dakota and America stay at the forefront of discovery. Since 2010, the Office of Science has awarded NDSU $6.3 million and UND $3.9 million for energy research, and biological and environment research. These funds have helped our universities stay on the map, and given our students and faculty critical firsthand experience and knowledge. In that same time period, the EERC received $33,000 to develop and deploy technologies that improve energy efficiency and environment performance associated with the fossil fuel industry. Investing in research and energy technologies is an investment in the future and it must remain a priority for our country.

I wake up every morning and think about rural America, and how I can best represent North Dakota in the U.S. Senate. Which is why when I saw the president’s budget, I was shocked by the drastic cuts that would leave rural America behind. The budget would eliminate Community Development Block Grants (CDBG), LIHEAP, Essential Air Service (EAS), and the Economic Development Administration (EDA) – all of which are critical in supporting our families, neighbors, and communities. In 2016, nearly $5 million in federal funding from CDBG was used in cities across the state to support low-income families and seniors, combat homelessness, and so much more. LIHEAP provides heating assistance to low-income households and supported 13,000 North Dakotans by helping them heat their homes during our harsh winter. EAS has been critical to reviving air travel in Dickinson, Devils Lake, and Jamestown – helping spur economic growth in each region. And since 2009, the EDA has invested $34 million in North Dakota which has led to $478 million in private investments. These cuts are just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the programs that the president’s budget would eliminate or severely reduce, and we need to fight to make sure these cuts don’t go into effect.

Check out the latest episode of my podcast, The Hotdish, featuring my fellow U.S. Senator for North Dakota John Hoeven, journalist Mick Kjar, and former USDA Rural Development state director Ryan Taylor. I brought together these folks to talk about fighting for the next Farm Bill and pushing back against proposals that would harm farmers, ranchers, and rural communities. The 21 percent cuts to USDA that the administration proposed are unworkable, and so are any trade policies that would make it tougher for producers to sell their top-notch crops abroad. ICYMI – this morning I was on CNBC’s Squawk Box to talk about getting the Export-Import Bank fully operating so it can support American businesses and workers, and the need for Congress to overcome partisanship and get to work for the American people.

The president’s budget would eliminate federal funding for Essential Air Service (EAS) – which airports in Devils Lake, Dickinson, and Jamestown rely on to sustain service. According to a study by the North Dakota Aeronautics Commission, the airport in Devils Lake, which receives $4 million annually through EAS, and its activities contribute more than $370,000 in annual state and local tax revenues and visitors from commercial flights spend over $1 million each year on local purchases. Supporting rural airports is a critical piece to supporting rural communities and economies. It’s irresponsible to eliminate a program that so many communities rely on and I’ll fight to make sure rural communities aren’t left behind.

The president’s budget leaves rural America behind by cutting critical programs that thousands of North Dakotans rely on keep their communities connected, heat their homes, and support the local economy. Programs like Community Development Block Grants (CDBG), LIHEAP, Essential Air Service (EAS), and the Economic Development Administration (EDA) would all be eliminated. These programs have invested millions into our communities and we’ve seen the impact that’s had. These cuts are just a quick look at how unfairly North Dakotans would be hurt by the president’s budget – and we need to fight to make sure this doesn’t go into effect.

Helped reintroduce bipartisan and bicameral bill that would ease the financial challenges of adopting children in tribal communities with special needs. In 2014, 100% of the 96 children that were adopted in North Dakota were identified as having special needs. Unfortunately, parents are unable to access full tax credit support when they adopt a child with special needs from tribal governments – but they can when they adopt through any of our nation’s 50 state governments. That puts children in Indian Country in need of safe, healthy environments at an immediate disadvantage – and it’s unacceptable.

Proud to join a bipartisan group of senators to push back against the president’s budget, which would eliminate federal funding for Essential Air Service (EAS). EAS guarantees airports in North Dakota communities like Devils Lake, Dickinson, and Jamestown have affordable air travel. Regular air service creates jobs, keeps families connected, and brings tourists into North Dakota. Cutting off this federal funding would hurt rural America, and it makes no sense to entirely eliminate a program that’s working well.

In the latest episode of my podcast, The Hotdish, I invited former USDA Rural Development state director and North Dakota rancher, Ryan Taylor, Senator John Hoeven, and journalist Mick Kjar to talk about agriculture in North Dakota. Listen on iTunes or SoundCloud to our conversations on the next Farm Bill, potential USDA budget cuts, and the need for tough trade policies that help our farmers, ranchers, and producers. http://bit.ly/2mU2HWV

On Monday, April 17 in Fargo and Thursday, April 20 in Bismarck, I’m holding public meetings to answer North Dakotans’ questions on health care and other issues. Hope to see folks there to discuss how I’m working to make sure your voices are heard in Washington. But if you can’t make it, you can watch it live from my Facebook page.

From 2014 to 2016, more than 48,000 low-income North Dakotans in more than 30,000 families received assistance through the Community Service Block Grants (CSBG) – which would be eliminated in the president’s budget. CSBG support programs for affordable housing, anti-poverty, infrastructure development, and more. Of the 48,000 North Dakotas who received support from these programs, 12,000 were children, nearly 8,000 were people with disabilities, almost 11,000 were seniors and more than 13,000 were people who lacked health insurance. Just because this federal funding would disappear doesn’t mean that these folks will too – we need an even-handed approach to the budget process that doesn’t hurt those who are most vulnerable.

Following last week’s change to U.S. Senate rules on Supreme Court nominees, I joined a bipartisan group of 60 other senators to call on Senate leaders to defend Senate rules that makes sure Congress works in a bipartisan way. We asked that leaders respect and preserve rules that require legislation to receive 60 votes to advance. That rule helps make sure legislation has buy-in from both sides of the aisle, leading to compromise solutions that reflect the best ideas from across the political spectrum. North Dakotans and the American people expect Congress to seek bipartisan solutions that stand up for them—as I’ve always worked to do—and we must make sure the Senate works that way, too.

Pressed U.S. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos about concerns over the agency’s announcement that it may revoke its commitment to provide student debt relief for borrowers who work in public service – such as in the military, teachers, or social workers – for 10 years. It’s unacceptable for the agency to go back on its word for both the individuals who have been diligently serving our communities and for the communities that benefit from their service. Governing by uncertainty is bad policy with real consequences and I’ll continue to call on Secretary DeVos to keep her agency’s promises to our students and public servants.

Investing in research is critical to ensure a bright future for our state and country. In 2016, the National Institute of Health awarded $22.5 million in grants and contracts to North Dakota that supported 447 jobs and $70 million in economic activity in our state. Not only does the National Institute of Health – which supports most of the country’s research on diseases and treatments - help North Dakota remain on the cutting edge of research and innovation, it also has a clear economic impact. The president’s budget would slash funding for NIH by 20%, limiting its economic impact in North Dakota.

Becoming a donor is a selfless and courageous act that has endless impacts on the person who receives it and their family. Alexa Kersting from West Fargo tragically died at the age of 14 while waiting for a lung transplant. Despite her and her family’s hope for a miracle, it sadly never came. Excited to announce that the Prairie Village Museum in Rugby is one of 65 museums, libraries, and universities across the country to host the Library for America’s World War I and American program over the next two years to honor our World War I veterans. This event will bring together historical resources and today’s veterans to discuss the role America played in winning World War I and how it helped establish America’s leadership role in the world. Honoring the memory of those who served overseas as well as those who were on the home front on the farms and factories used to power the war effort is critical to understanding where we have been and more importantly to respect the sacrifices they made.
