The president’s budget would eliminate Community Development Block Grants – which communities across North Dakota rely on to address specific needs and support some of the most vulnerable North Dakotans. For example, over 4,000 at-risk youth have received support from agencies like YouthWorks, Charles Hall Youth Services, and Carrie’s Kids – all of which have used CDBG funds for ongoing renovation projects. At-risk, homeless, and runaway youth are often the easiest and most susceptible targets for human traffickers and for other horrific crimes. We have a responsibility to provide necessary resources, shelter, and services for these young people so they realize someone out there does care about them. I’ll fight to make sure we don’t cut programs like CDBG that are essential to making sure our communities can live up to our responsibilities and protect those most vulnerable.

Today the president signed into law a bill that I helped introduce and pass to extend the VA Choice Program so veterans can get care closer to home. The bill also makes needed reforms to cut down on costs and confusion for veterans in North Dakota and around the country. But the job isn’t done. Until the Choice Program works for veterans across our state, I’ll keep pushing for reforms to guarantee veterans don’t have to drive hundreds of miles for life-saving cancer treatments, check-ups, or other medical care they need.

Watch live as I hold my second public meeting this week to answer North Dakotans’ questions on health care and other issues, as well as discuss how I’m working to make sure North Dakotans’ voices are heard in Washington.

Thanks to all the folks in Bismarck who came to my public meeting today to ask questions and share concerns about health care and other issues. Our discussion covered everything from mental health and defending Medicaid, to making sure our veterans get the care they deserve. There were also excellent questions about other issues—like keeping North Dakota’s public schools strong, and attracting a diverse workforce by making it clear that discrimination isn’t welcome in our state. If you couldn’t make it to the meeting, check out the video on my Facebook page and reach out to my office with any questions.

The president’s budget would cut Essential Air Service – a program that by ensuring regular, affordable air service, helps create jobs, keep families connected, and bring tourists into North Dakota. According to a North Dakota Aeronautics Commission impact study in 2015, Jamestown’s airport – one of three that rely on EAS in North Dakota – has an economic benefit of more than $24.4 million. And from 2013 – 2016, boardings increased by 316% - signaling strong support for the community and region. Last week I joined a bipartisan group of 19 other senators to reinforce that cutting off federal funding for EAS would hurt rural America, and it makes no sense to  eliminate a program that’s working well.

Investing in energy efficiency programs helps save low income families and tribal members money, while providing proper weatherproofing to withstand North Dakota’s harsh weather conditions. Since 2010, North Dakota has received $12.2 million in federal funding through the Weatherization Assistance Program – which the president’s budget would eliminate – to improve the energy efficiency of 1,320 homes.  A true all-of-the-above energy strategy means boosting efficiency and making sure our energy sources remain reliable and affordable well into the future, and cutting a program that works to do that is unacceptable.

North Dakotans have a strong sense of community and commitment to life. Which is why it is no surprise that in 2013, roughly 70% of drivers were registered as an organ donor compared to 45% nationally. Saying yes to becoming an organ donor is a small sacrifice that can mean the matter of life or death for so many folks. During National Donate Life Month this month, let’s honor those who have donated and raise awareness about the incredible impacts of organ donors.

The president’s budget would eliminate federal funding for long distance Amtrak train services – potentially ending the Empire Builder route that goes through North Dakota. Long-distance train service is important to connect North Dakota communities across the region. In 2016, nearly 30,000 North Dakotas used Amtrak in Minot alone. Read more in this Minot Daily News article.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Voted with a bipartisan majority of the U.S. Senate to confirm former Georgia Governor Sonny Perdue as Secretary of Agriculture. Now that he’s been confirmed by the Senate, I’ll make sure Secretary Perdue understands North Dakotans’ serious concerns about the president’s budget, which would slash USDA funding by an astonishing 21%—entirely eliminating programs that safeguard rural water. I look forward to working with Secretary Perdue on my bipartisan bill – which he endorsed during his confirmation hearing – to expand U.S. agriculture exports to Cuba. Secretary Perdue impressed me at our one-on-one meeting and at his hearing, and looking ahead I’ll push him to be a strong voice for rural America, and a voice for the policies our producers need.

North American energy independence is possible with a true all-of-the-above energy strategy, which includes continuing to make investments in energy conservation through efficiency. Since 2010, North Dakota has received $1.7 million from the U.S. Department of Energy State Energy Program to advance clean energy through community programs – which the president’s budget would eliminate. These funds have supported 263 community events for nearly 230,000 North Dakotans, as well as programs like eFargo that reduced energy consumption and saved residents over $4 million, and North Dakota’s first community solar garden. Cutting the primary source of funding for energy efficiency education outreach, like the president’s budget would do, hurts our communities and hinders our ability to achieve a true all-of-the-above energy strategy.

Had a great chat with a group of coal miners from Alabama today who stopped by to talk about what they’re doing to secure the health care that was promised to them. Included in this group were four amazing women who worked down in the mines for over 30 years, working hard for the benefits they were offered. Coal miners across the country, like the folks I met with today, and workers in North Dakota have helped build our country with their own sweat and labor, and they keep the lights on in homes for families in every one of our states. But for years, the federal government and coal operators have failed to give them certainty and honor their obligation of lifetime pensions and health benefits to retired miners and their families. Taking away hard-earned benefits – whether it’s health care or pensions – that were promised to working men and women is unacceptable. If we’re going to be a country that rewards hard work, than we need to live up to our commitments and I’ll continue to stand with coal miners, Teamsters, and workers across the country to make sure we do.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Although North Dakotans can safely dispose of unused or unwanted prescription drugs all year, I encourage folks to participate in and help spread the word that this Saturday, April 29 is National Drug Take-Back Day. Prescription drug abuse has made its way into too many North Dakota homes and communities, and Drug Take-Back Day is an opportunity for us to all do our part in the fight against prescription drug abuse. Especially since more than half of prescription drugs are obtained through friends or family – usually without them knowing.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Native students are among America’s most underserved youth, and for years the federal government has been neglecting its duty to help them access learning opportunities that can help them thrive. By updating decades old data the federal government uses to determine federal funding for critical cultural and educational support for Native students, Senator Lankford and I introduced a bipartisan bill that would prevent Native children from falling through the cracks. We need strong bipartisan solution like this bill to build access to critical learning programs Native students need to succeed, and to create opportunities that make sure no Native child is forgotten.

Introduced a bipartisan, commonsense bill with Republican U.S. Senator Rob Portman from Ohio to make sure we have smarter, more effective regulations. Federal regulations keep our air clean and families safe, and no one wants to go back to an era without safety standards. But sometimes regulations don’t work as intended and create red tape. All across North Dakota, the biggest concern I hear from business owners and workers is about regulations hurting their abilities to do their jobs. Our bipartisan bill would make federal regulations smarter and more effective for everyone impacted by them, support job growth, create certainty, and provide an important check and balance on the president no matter who is in charge.

At a Senate Committee hearing, I pressed expert witnesses on how Congress can send a clear message to Russia that we stand united, and won’t let it engage in cyberattacks or election interference against our country with impunity. When I invited experts from the Wilson Center to host an event at the University of North Dakota last month, they reinforced the importance of taking Russia seriously and staying tough to deter its aggression. That’s a message I echoed today, and I’ll keep working to hold Russia accountable—and looking for opportunities where North Dakota can play a role, like bolstering our nuclear deterrent and potential Arctic missions.

Last week, one of my good friends and blind veteran, Eric Marts, participated in a week-long training camp that is the same as the Mountain Phase of Ranger School with four other blind veterans. Throughout the week, Eric and his team navigated man-made obstacles, rope bridges, repelled from a tower, and climbed the sheer face of Mount Yonah. Eric has always strived to show folks that no matter what challenges they face, they can rise above – and taking on this training is another example of that determination. I’m so proud to call Eric my friend and of his endless pursuit to help and inspire others.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Now that we have a new Defense Secretary, I again called on the Defense Department to speed up the plans to replace Vietnam-era UN-1N helicopters, including helicopters located at Minot Air Force Base. The Air Force has said over and over that these helicopters need to be replaced. The hardworking airmen at Minot Air Force Base deserve the best aircraft possible as they protect the vital nuclear deterrent at the base.

During National Tribal Colleges and Universities Week in February, I had the opportunity to meet with inspiring and resilient Native students from North Dakota’s tribal colleges. Watch below to hear how their tribal colleges have had life-changing impacts on their lives, reinforcing the critical role of tribal colleges and universities to help their students flourish. The dedication of these institutions to each student – many of whom have to overcome overwhelming obstacles of poverty, trauma, and abuse – is why I led a bipartisan group of 17 senators to designate a week to honor National Tribal Colleges and Universities. I’m incredibly proud of each of these students, and the many others, who have work so hard to get a good education.

It’s great news that a permanent solution to provide coal miners the health care they were promised is included in the federal funding bill Congress reached a deal on last night. Last week, a group of retired coal miners from Alabama stopped by my office to talk about their continued push to get the benefits they earned. It’s because of the dedication of miners across the country and passionate advocates like U.S. Senate Joe Manchin, who led the charge for a solution in Congress, that Congress is able to tell these folks that the federal government will fulfill its commitment and provide what was promised to them. Whether it’s health care or pensions, it’s critical to stand up for workers throughout their lives – and I’ll always stand behind workers, including those who have put their sweat and labor into their jobs day in and out for decades to help keep our country running.

We have taken two important steps forward to get the Commission on Native Children – which was created by my bill that became law last October – up and running. The Commission will soon receive the federal funding it needs to operate, and we have another devoted member on the Commission, Dr. Tami DeCoteau from Bismarck, who has dedicated her life’s work to healing of the deep generational and systemic wounds Native children and families carry. Now that this Commission will have the funding it needs to begin its crucial work, we need to get the rest of the members of the Commission on board so they can get started on providing lasting solutions designed to improve outcomes for Native children.

In American in 2017, people are still fired and discriminated against because of their sexual orientation or gender identity. This is unacceptable. We cannot allow discrimination of any form. That’s why I’m proud to support and help reintroduce the Equality Act – a historic bill that would strengthen LGBT nondiscrimination policies and make sure everyone is treated equally under the law. #EqualityForward

Introduced bipartisan legislation that would level the playing field for tribal coal developments by making sure tribal communities can depend on fair competition with federal, state, and private projects that don’t face the same high level of regulatory scrutiny. When tribes have the proper encouragement and support to ramp up the coal producing projects that can grow jobs and help support their local economy, that’s good for Indian Country, our economy, and our nation’s all-of-the-above energy strategy.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Great to catch up with Marisol Nichols today to talk about her important work to combat human trafficking through her organization, Foundation for a Slavery Free World. Marisol and I met last July to talk about our shared passion of protecting those who are most vulnerable. And this year, Marisol is in Washington, D.C. to receive the Presidential Volunteer Service Award from Youth for Human Rights. It’s great to have strong partners like Marisol in the fight against human trafficking.

State and city-run initiatives give the 41% of the private sector employees – which is roughly 112,00 workers – in North Dakota who work for an employer that does not offer a retirement plan the ability to save for their future. It’s unacceptable that today the U.S. Senate voted to eliminate these retirement options – hurting hardworking men and women in North Dakota and across rural America who work hard and play by the rules to try to make an honest living and save for retirement. Congress has to stand up for workers throughout their lives – including into retirement -- and it’s disappointing that it didn’t do that today. This bill was wrong, and I’ll continue to stand up for the workers who built this country.

North Dakota farmers, ranchers, utilities, and small business owners still need certainty about how the administration is going to roll back or rewrite unworkable regulations like the Clean Power Plan and the Waters of the U.S. rule—and that’s what I pressed EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt for today. Just as I pushed the previous administration to make regulations work better without jeopardizing programs that protect clean air and water in North Dakota, I’ll do the same with this administration.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Met with Major General Alan Dohrmann, the leader of the North Dakota National Guard, to discuss his top priorities—including a bill I signed onto at his request to help support the National Guard. North Dakota’s National Guard has a hard-earned reputation for excellence. Under the leadership of Major General Dohrmann, the Guard has served the people of North Dakota, worked to keep our families safe, and stepped up to take on missions around the globe that are critical to our national security. Congress shouldn’t get in the way of the brave work these citizen-soldiers and airmen do, which is why I’m hopeful this bipartisan bill can help reduce requirements to convert dual-status technicians—those who currently serve both as military and civilian personnel—to solely civilian roles, making sure the policy doesn’t have adverse consequences for leaders like General Dohrmann.

Today Congress passed a bipartisan compromise spending bill to fund the federal government through September 2017. This bill includes many provisions I fought for to support North Dakota and rural America to help address the challenges we face.  This bipartisan agreement provides needed federal funding and support to address our nation’s opioid abuse epidemic – a tragedy that too many families and communities have felt in North Dakota.   It also provides federal funds to a program that the state of North Dakota could apply for to be reimbursed for some of the costs on law enforcement needed to keep communities safe during protests around the Dakota Access pipeline. At a time when the state has budget challenges, I hope they apply for these federal funds.   It includes funding for my Commission on Native Children – which was created when my bill was signed into law last October. This means as soon as members are appointed, the Commission can get to work to find solutions to better support Native youth.   Through this spending bill, Congress finally fulfills its promise to retired coal miners by permanently extending the health benefits they were promised. This was a matter of life and death for so many folks and I’m proud to have been fighting with coal miners across the country. Now we need to keep fighting to make sure they receive the retirement benefits they and other workers, including those in the Central States Pension Fund, earned.

Today I met with Grand Forks leaders to reinforce all the strengths we can highlight when General Robinson visits North Dakota—a visit the general promised me when I sat down with her in December. Grand Forks has so many assets, and we need to make sure the Air Force sees them. My goal earlier this year when I brought community leaders and two of our country’s top Russia experts together was to bolster Grand Forks’ leadership in the Arctic. It’s also great news that the spending bill I helped pass today in the U.S. Senate includes $8 million in needed federal funding for a new Customs and Border Protection facility at the base. The Global Hawks, Grand Sky, and UND’s aviation school have already put the community on the map—and I’m working to make sure the Air Force recognizes those assets so we can attract future missions.

In 2000, I was diagnosed with breast cancer. Seventeen years ago, I beat it thanks to the world class doctors who took care of me, the enduring support of my family and friends, and the quality health insurance that enabled me to get the care I needed. I was fortunate. But under the Republican health care bill passed in the U.S. House of Representatives today, many Americans and North Dakotans, including children, could lose health coverage if they have preexisting conditions, like cancer, heart disease, asthma, or when a woman is pregnant. It’s during those times when we need affordable, quality health care the most.    I’ve long said there are good pieces of the health reform law and pieces that need to be fixed. Since 2013, I’ve met regularly with my health care advisory board – comprised of health care leaders across North Dakota – to discuss health care in the state and how to improve the health reform law. Over the past three and a half years, I have offered many reasonable, transparent reforms to the health reform law to make it work better.   But ripping away families’ health care, as the Republican bill would do, isn’t the answer. Rather, it’s a recipe for disaster. This bill would make health care less accessible and less affordable for too many. It’s well past time to stop politics and do policy. That’s what I’ve been trying to accomplish because no family should have to choose between getting critical care for a loved one or facing bankruptcy.

Helped reintroduce a bipartisan bill to give states the option of leveling the playing field for brick and mortar businesses. As we shop online more and more, small businesses across North Dakota that support good jobs and help grow our local economies lose out – and this bill works to address that. Since serving as North Dakota’s Tax Commissioner, I’ve been working to level the playing field so mom and pop shops are not discriminated against through unfair tax policies. We can level the playing field for our local businesses by giving states the option to make sure the marketplace – online or in stores – is fair and that’s what my bill aims to do.

The president’s 2018 budget would effectively eliminate the Office of National Drug Control Policy – the federal agency that is coordinating the fight against opioid abuse. As the drug crisis tears apart rural areas, Indian Country, and towns across North Dakota, I won’t stand by and let the administration dismantle the federal agency leading the coordinated, comprehensive fight against drug trafficking and drug abuse. Imagine trying to steer a ship when everyone’s rowing in different directions. That’s what our response to the opioid epidemic would look like without this agency. As North Dakotans saw when I brought the directors of the agency to our state in 2013 and 2014, this office brings together federal, state, and local agencies with skin in the game to guarantee a united response to this crisis—while also providing federal grants that are a lifeline as North Dakota communities fight the crisis. I've held listening sessions across North Dakota – in Bismarck, Jamestown, Grand Forks, Fargo, and Minot – to bring together community leaders to tackle the opioid abuse epidemic and discuss federal support for these communities. We can't take away federal resources when they are most needed.

At one school in Bismarck, North Dakota, Burleigh County Social Services visited 130 times in one year to investigate abuse and neglect charges. At the same school, 181 students – almost half of all the students there – live at or below poverty. A seven year old boy who was adopted was having a tough day at school one day because that afternoon he had his therapy appointment to say his final goodbye to his birth mother. The young boy made a map to show his mom how she can find him again someday – but his mom never showed up to the therapy appointment to say goodbye. Unfortunately these are some of the countless stories from just this one school. Exposure to abandonment, poverty, neglect, and abuse are traumatic experiences that have both emotional and physiological impacts on everyone – but especially young children who are still developing. That’s why for the past  year, I’ve been bringing in experts on the impacts of childhood trauma to Capitol Hill to raise awareness about the impacts and discuss what we can do to combat it, and to also build an army of people who believe we can change outcomes. In addition to these briefings, I introduced legislation that would address and mitigate the detrimental impact exposure to trauma can have on children and families – particularly those in Native communities – as they grow and develop. Addressing and limiting exposure to childhood trauma is a long-term strategy for real change in America.

Spread the word – there’s a new scam affecting veterans who are making decisions about their health care. Scammers have set up a phony telephone line that is very similar to the correct line for the Veterans Choice Program. The correct Veterans Choice Program phone number is 1-866-606-8198. You’ll know if you reached the fake phone line if you are offered a $100 rebate if you provide a credit card and if the person on the other end does not say that you’ve reached the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs of Veterans Choice Program phone line. If you’re unsure if you’ve reached the right phone line, hang up and dial 1-866-606-8198 again.

The CBO report that came out today confirms that the Republican health care bill is just cruel and is bad for North Dakota. The bill would rip away health care from 23 million Americans by 2026, including more than 28,000 North Dakotans. It would also make coverage unaffordable for the more than 300,000 North Dakotans with pre-existing conditions like asthma, cancer, or being pregnant. And it would disproportionately hurt those in rural communities like families all across North Dakota who rely on rural health clinics and rural hospitals for coverage. The biggest savings in the bill would come from about $830 billion in cuts to Medicaid -- a lifesaving, cost effective program that has enabled more than 90,000 seniors, individuals and children with disabilities, and low-income families in North Dakota get affordable, quality care. It is also is a critical resource for individuals receiving treatment for opioid abuse and addiction which has reached epidemic levels in our state. But here’s the kicker: the bill would do all of this while giving individuals making more than $200,000 a tax cut. That isn’t right. In fact, it’s downright mean. Those who voted for this bill should know better – it was a vote for their own self-interest, and certainly not one that stands up for the people of our country or North Dakota.   I’ve long said there are good pieces of the health reform law and pieces that need to be fixed, and that’s a conversation I have wanted to have for years. In 2013, I convened the initial meeting with my health care advisory board made up of health care leaders from across the state and we have continued to meet to talk about how to improve the health reform law. Over the past three and a half years, I’ve offered a variety of reforms to make sure the health reform law works better for families and businesses. Republicans and Democrats need to have this critical conversation, and I’m willing to work with anyone to do what is best for my state. But this bill, which is terrible for North Dakota, is a non-starter.

Today the president announced he would withdraw the US from the Paris climate deal. The United States can’t remain an energy leader if we aren’t even at the negotiating table. No agreement is perfect, and adjusting our commitments or timetable would have been viable avenues to pursue. But abandoning this agreement altogether is a reckless decision that forfeits an opportunity to guarantee a viable future for North Dakota coal, oil, and natural gas on the global level. We have to acknowledge the reality that all countries—the United States included—must work to reduce emissions, and we can do it in a way that maintains a strong future for fossil fuels and renewables by working with other countries to accomplish those goals. Yet, with this move, the United States is ceding its leadership role to China. Without a strong U.S. voice pushing to invest in carbon capture technologies, as I’ve been fighting for, it’s also less likely that coal will remain a viable part of our energy mix in a carbon-constrained world. Additionally, leaving the deal signals that this administration isn’t serious about wind and other North Dakota renewable resources, which businesses and homeowners are demanding more and more. And it shows a lack of commitment to a true all-of-the-above energy strategy, investment in U.S. companies, and good American jobs across all energy sectors. This agreement isn’t a partisan issue. Utilities, energy companies, former diplomats, and more have urged the U.S. to remain in the deal.   Diplomatically, the United States is retreating. More than 190 countries signed this agreement, and just two opposed it—one of which is Syria. For generations, our country has been a global leader, dictating the conversation around the world on a host of issues. With this move, that now changes, and I fear we’ll be left behind on climate and energy issues as well as many others.

Today in Dickinson, I brought together leaders in health care, treatment, and law enforcement for my sixth in-state meeting on combating the opioid epidemic in our state. We also talked about how the Republican health care bill would cripple access to critical services and opioid treatment. Instead of fighting back – with the law enforcement, health professionals, and families that are battling this crisis to save their communities – the Republican health care bill would strip vital Medicaid resources for North Dakotans receiving treatment for opioid abuse and addiction. Medicaid pays for over a third of all medication-assisted treatment nationwide and 17.4% of opioid treatment payments in North Dakota. Now is not the time to retreat – I certainly won’t. I’ll keep fighting for and with the North Dakota communities and rural health services so we can combat this epidemic together and win.

ICYMI – AARP’s North Dakota state president, Kathi Schwan, wrote about how the Republican health care bill that passed in the U.S. House of Representatives would disproportionally hurt older Americans, including those throughout our state. By allowing insurance companies to charge more for those with pre-existing conditions like heart disease or asthma, reducing tax credits, and cutting Medicaid, thousands of older North Dakotans could see sky-rocketing prices for less coverage. That’s unacceptable.

In Dickinson, about 475 jobs are dependent on the airport, which helped generate $76.6 million for the area in 2015. Today with airport and community leaders at the Theodore Roosevelt Regional Airport, I reinforced the importance of Essential Air Service, a federal program that enables airlines to serve rural communities and provides the Dickinson airport with $4.2 million each year. But that the president’s budget would cut this program, hurting rural communities. These funds help support small business growth and local jobs in Dickinson, make it possible for residents to travel, and boost tourism to the area. But without EAS support during difficult times, Dickinson would lose commercial air travel options—costing Dickinson jobs. I’ve long been an advocate for EAS funding because it helps enable many of our communities get needed support to thrive, and I’ll work to make sure these cuts don’t go through.

Dr. Fadel Nammour is a physician and currently working as a gastroenterologist in Fargo where he serves as vice president of the North Dakota Medical Association. He moved to North Dakota from Lebanon 14 years ago. Like many doctors in North Dakota, Dr. Nammour came to our state through the Conrad 30 program that allows international doctors to remain in the U.S. after their residency under the condition that they practice in underserved areas, such as rural communities, helping bring good doctors to communities that often have doctor shortages, as is the case for many North Dakota towns. North Dakota relies on the Conrad 30 program to make sure it has the doctors needed to provide quality and affordable care right in our home. That’s why I helped introduce a bipartisan bill to extend the Conrad 30 program – which is currently set to expire in September – until 2021. Conrad 30 is a successful two-decade-old program that has helped families across rural America.

Essential Air Service – which the president’s budget would eliminate – is a federal program that enables airlines to serve rural communities, including many in North Dakota. Last week, I visited Theodore Roosevelt Regional Airport in Dickinson to hear firsthand about how important this program is to the community and region and the need to continue the EAS program. In Dickinson, about 475 jobs are dependent on the airport, which helped generate $76.6 million for the area in 2015. EAS provides the Dickinson airport with $4.2 million each year, which helps support local economic development, create jobs, and boost tourism. But the president’s budget would eliminate this needed program, hurting rural communities like Dickinson, Jamestown, and Devils Lake that rely on EAS. I’ve long been an advocate for EAS funding because it helps enable many of our communities get needed support to thrive, and I’ll work to make sure these cuts don’t go through.

We must prioritize tough, smart border security strategies to support the long-term safety of our communities – but unfortunately, the president’s budget doesn’t do enough to protect the Northern Border. Today at a U.S. Senate Committee hearing, I called on U.S. Department of Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly to keep in mind the impacts of cutting local grant programs on our ability to keep our border secure. I also questioned him on plans for the Northern Border and my strong concern that the budget leaves our ports of entry by the wayside. It’s time to get serious and I’ll keep pressing Secretary Kelly for commonsense policies on border security. http://bit.ly/2sPZxU2
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Today I met with folks from the Committee to Protect Pensions to talk about the future of the Central States Pension Fund. For decades, 40,000 American workers – including 2,000 in North Dakota – worked back-breaking jobs to support their families with the promise of a good pension and retirement security. Now, through no fault of their own, they are seeing their pensions – and their futures – at risk. This is unacceptable. We need to reward hard work by making sure families’ retirement savings are secure and will be there when they most need it. Click here to read some of the stories of how pension cuts could impact North Dakotans: http://bit.ly/2sOKl9q

Mexican sugar dumping hurts sugar growers across North Dakota, and I’ve long fought for a solution that protects our producers. This agreement between the U.S. and Mexico to curb Mexican sugar dumping is a good step, but as I reinforced to USDA Secretary Perdue today, I’m concerned about provisions Mexico could exploit to violate the agreement – again threatening the good-paying jobs our domestic sugar growers create in the Red River Valley. Secretary Perdue assured me he would pursue enforcement if Mexico violates the agreement, and as this agreement is implemented I’ll work with North Dakota sugar growers to hold him to his word.

Today the president nominated United States District Judge Ralph Erickson to serve on the 8th Circuit Court of Appeals. Judge Erickson has proven through his decades of experience, record of impartiality, and devotion to his work that he is a judicious and thoughtful lawyer who continues to follow the rule of law. I have known Judge Erickson for many years and he has a reputation for fairness and independence, and is highly respected by members of the North Dakota bar – and I look forward to supporting his nomination in the U.S. Senate.

North Dakota is only as strong as our rural communities and the farmers and ranchers who drive rural economies—but this budget would leave them out to dry. When one in every four North Dakotans is a farmer, rancher, or works in a farm-related job, it’s clear that slashing crop insurance and other vital programs would harm our entire state. These programs help our farmers and ranchers feed the world and keep rural America strong—and that’s what I reinforced to the president, calling on him to support strong rural development policies and reject budget cuts that threaten our small towns and rural economies. Watch the full video from my speech on the floor of the U.S. Senate: http://bit.ly/2rCyoWZ
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

One of the many ways the president’s budget would cripple infrastructure in rural America is by eliminating the Empire Building Amtrak route in the upper Midwest and in the Pacific Northwest. In addition to getting rid of this route, the president’s budget would also eliminates a federal grant program that supports transportation infrastructure growth. You can’t expect rural America to grow and thrive while at the same time disconnecting it from the rest of the world. The Amtrak line keeps businesses in rural America competitive and supports tourism, and it’s important that we maintain these tools.

Introduced a bipartisan bill with Republican U.S. Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona to help address chronic challenges Customs and Border Protection faces with hiring and retaining a vibrant, quality workforce along our nation’s borders to help improve border staffing and security. When I visit Portal and Pembina, both remote ports along our nation’s 5,500-mile long Northern Border, and talk with the dedicated officers manning those ports, I see the stress that is caused by the vacancies and other workforce challenges at such locations. This bipartisan bill would give CBP the authority it needs to develop better hiring and retention strategies that work on the ground - commonsense principles from my Flexible HIRE Act which identify the struggles CBP faces in remote areas.

Great to have key leaders in community banking – including Steve Grooms, the president and CEO of 1st Liberty Federal Credit Union which as a branch in Grand Forks – at a U.S. Senate hearing today focused on long-term solutions to support families and businesses that rely on relationship-based lending. In North Dakota alone, 80% of deposits are held at small banks and credit unions. Families purchasing their first homes, small businesses working to expand, and ranchers and farmers planning for the future all rely on small institutions for the relationship-based lending they’ve trusted for generations. That’s why I’ve offered a host of bills that will help make sure small, local banks don’t get consumed by expensive, time-consuming red tape and can continue to do what they do best and support our families and businesses. http://bit.ly/2sZ97ny
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

To help support North Dakota veterans, I joined a bipartisan group of senators to call for robust federal funding for state veterans homes—including the veterans home in Lisbon, which provides long-term care to North Dakota vets. State veterans homes have a long history of making sure veterans receive the respect and dignity they have earned through their service. In fact, the veterans home in Lisbon has served our state’s veterans since 1893. Those services are especially vital in a rural state like North Dakota.

Check out the Bismarck Vet Center’s Open House/BBQ on June 16 and 17 for PTSD Awareness month and to learn more about the services it provides for local veterans. Recently, the Bismarck Vet Center has hired new staff to expand their free counseling services. I encourage folks to check out the Open House and spread the word about the free counseling, screening, and referral services.

North Dakotans know all too well the importance of permanent flood protection – and the president’s budget slashing $856 million from the Army Corps of Engineers construction funding could put critical flood protection projects in North Dakota in jeopardy. To make matters worse, the president’s budget would also eliminate U.S. Department of Agriculture funding to protect water programs in rural areas. This would leave behind a huge backlog of demand and impact millions of rural Americans. Since 2010, USDA in North Dakota has financed over $111 million to improve water and wastewater systems in more than 40 cities, tribal reservations, or water districts. Rural communities need clean drinking water and reliable water systems to maintain, and recklessly cutting programs that help make that happen clearly shows that rural America is not a priority for this administration.

Like thousands of other North Dakotans, Wayne Burlog from Grand Forks is worried about how his family will access and afford health insurance under the Republican health care bill that already passed in the U.S. House of Representatives. Health care shouldn’t be about scoring petty political points, it should be about finding commonsense, bipartisan solutions that make sure folks have access to quality health care and that those most vulnerable don’t have the rug pulled out from under them. Unfortunately, the Republican health care bill would make health care too expensive for many North Dakotans to afford, and it would enable insurance companies to charge those with pre-existing conditions, like cancer, diabetes, or asthma dramatically more for coverage, essentially taking care away from many individuals and families.  I’ll keep fighting in the Senate to make sure North Dakotans get the health care they deserve and can afford.

The president’s budget -- which would limit crop insurance eligibly by one-third and introduce a cap of $40,000 on crop insurance premium subsidies – would alter the crop insurance program in a way that would severely undermine farmer safety net programs and provide more uncertainty in an already volatile commodity market. This AgWeek editorial summarizes how uncertain agriculture is and why drastic cuts and changes to how the farm safety net operates would hurt farmers and ranchers. We have to give producers the tools and safety net they need to continue their work to feed the world, and throughout the budget process and talks on the 2018 Farm Bill, I’ll fight to make sure we keep in place essential programs for our agriculture communities. http://bit.ly/2slnczz

To guarantee a realistic future for coal—and for good-paying coal jobs in North Dakota—I’ve led 15 diverse Democratic senators in urging Congress to provide strong federal funding for U.S. Energy Department programs that develop carbon capture, utilization, and storage technologies. Those federal investments are needed to advance a true all-of-the-above energy strategy, and to maintain coal as a reliable, redundant power source for years to come. But the president’s budget would put that opportunity on the chopping block. In an increasingly carbon constrained world, this technology is key to coal’s future, which is why I’ve been working to bring together Republicans and Democrats to support innovative solutions to protect coal and the good-paying jobs it creates in North Dakota.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Medicaid provides affordable, quality health care for thousands of North Dakota children and individuals with disabilities, seniors, and low-income families, including Allison Restemayer from West Fargo. When Allison was almost two years old, she was diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder. Allison’s mother, Jennifer, and father were told that Allison would become severely mentally delayed by age three, and that she would likely pass away by the time she turned 10 years old. Today, Allison is 16 years old thanks to an amazing new, but very expensive therapy that has slowed the progression of her disorder. But Allison’s disorder is progressive and regenerative, so if she isn’t as mobile as possible, she regresses quicker. That means that Allison needs to do a minimum of one physical therapy session per week -- but really, she needs to do much more than that. Allison’s primary insurance covers only 12 physical therapy visits per year, but due to the support provided by Medicaid, Allison is able to get regular physical therapy sessions – including from her school -- without bankrupting her family. Medicaid has been a lifeline for Allison.  But unfortunately for Jennifer and Allison, I can’t tell them if the Republican health care bill being discussed in the U.S. Senate will affect them and their access to Medicaid. I can’t tell them because I haven’t been given the opportunity to read it. Just like the bill the U.S. House of Representatives passed, it’s being crafted in secret. That’s unacceptable. Writing and negotiating a health care bill that will affect millions of Americans should be done in an open and transparent process – not behind closed doors. I may not know what’s in the bill, but I will fight for Jennifer and Allison and North Dakotans all across the state who deserve access to affordable and quality health care.

Great news that my bipartisan bill with Republican U.S. Senator John McCain of Arizona to expand child abduction warnings – or AMBER Alert – in Indian Country unanimously passed through U.S. Senate Committee today. When a child is abducted or goes missing, law enforcement relies on AMBER Alert systems to help bring them to safety. But earlier this month when I asked North Dakota’s tribal leaders to raise their hands if such alerts existed on their reservations, not a single person raised their hand. That’s telling. Across the nation, when such alerts do exist in Indian Country, they’re often limited to tribal lands and don’t reach the public and law enforcement beyond the reservation – a vulnerability criminals can too easily exploit. That’s unacceptable and my bipartisan bill aims to fix that.

Had a great discussion with my good friend Ryan Taylor today. Those who know Ryan often recognize him by his cowboy hat, but today in Washington, Ryan was wearing another hat – he was here on behalf of Bread for the World with a few other folks to talk about anti-hunger and anti-poverty programs. When Ryan served as North Dakota State Director for USDA Rural Development, he saw firsthand the impact programs like SNAP had all across our state, and just last month, we got together in North Dakota to talk with a room full of folks to highlight the life-changing impact those programs have on thousands of North Dakotans and why we need to continue to invest in these programs that support North Dakotans and rural communities.

This story is a good example of worker shortages I’ve heard about from small businesses, manufacturers, and construction companies across North Dakota. I agree and have been urging companies to try to hire American workers, but as mentioned in this story, so many of these companies try unsuccessfully to hire American workers and rely on foreign workers to remain open. With the demand and processing backlog of H-2B visas – which are used by folks outside of the United States to come for temporary, seasonal work, many businesses aren’t able to fill the positions they need to function at full capacity. I’ve been pushing on the administration to work quickly and cut down on unnecessary red tape and delays so businesses have the certainty they need to plan for the season and hire workers.

Griffin is one of thousands of North Dakotans with a pre-existing condition. When he was four years old, he was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes, and now at the age of 10, he needs insulin every day to stay alive. Under the Republican health care bill that passed in the U.S. House of Representatives, coverage for folks with pre-existing conditions would skyrocket, making it difficult for families like Griffin’s to afford health care in the future. Unfortunately, I can’t tell Griffin what the U.S. Senate health care bill will mean for him because it’s being written behind closed doors, just as the bill the U.S. House of Representatives passed was. We now know the House bill would make health care for Griffin and so many others unaffordable. That isn’t right. All North Dakotans – including Griffin -- deserve access to quality and affordable health care.

As the president considers rolling back the United States’ diplomatic opening with Cuba, I urged him to consider how rural American has benefited from the opening. North Dakota farmers who grow beans, peas, and lentils look to Cuba as a growing market—and this administration shouldn’t make that market harder to reach. If the U.S.-Cuba policy is reversed, it would hurt future opportunities for our farmers to sell their top-notch crops to a hungry market just 100 miles from U.S. shores. I’ve been fighting to open this market to American producers – and the president should do the same.

Protecting our security means staying tough on Iran and holding Russia accountable when it meddles in our democracy – and sanctions I helped pass with a bipartisan majority of the U.S. Senate today accomplish both goals. Strong, smart, targeted sanctions brought Iran to the negotiating table for the nuclear deal that has prevented it from acquiring nuclear weapons, and these new sanctions aim to keep Iran in check for destabilizing behavior like its ballistic missiles program. The sanctions also target Russia for cyberattacks on the U.S., and destabilizing behavior in Ukraine and Syria.

Today at a U.S. Senate subcommittee hearing I helped lead, I reinforced how vital Farm Service Agency and Natural Resource Conservation Service field staff is for North Dakota farmers and ranchers. I also urged USDA not to let president's proposed budget cuts harm the important work those field offices do to strengthen rural communities. Local FSA offices are a lifeline in rural communities across North Dakota – just ask anyone who raises cattle or puts a crop in the ground. With a federal hiring freeze, folks in North Dakota have already been hurt by short-staffed offices that are unable to fill vacant positions. That’s unacceptable in the middle of a drought and a tough farm economy, when our producers need resources and support more than ever to help feed our country and the world. http://bit.ly/2rBeHLz
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Great to talk with driven young North Dakotans and help celebrate the 75th Anniversary of North Dakota Boys State in Wahpeton today. North Dakota Boys State has a long history of shaping young men into local and national leaders and the potential I saw in this great group of students is no exception. North Dakota Boys State is an incredible opportunity for young men to meet peers from across the state, gain valuable leadership skills, and receive a hands-on look at the government process. It was great to meet these young leaders and encourage them to work hard to reach their full potential.

We know our farmers and ranchers count on steady rains to provide moisture for their crops and pastures where cattle can graze – but when that rain doesn’t come, we have to be prepared. Across central and western North Dakota, I’ve heard from ranchers who tell me this May was the driest they’ve ever seen for this time of year – and that the recent small sprinkle of rain combined with strong winds didn’t make a dent in helping their pastures to recover. That’s why I’m launching my webpage for farmers and ranchers who have been hit hard by the drought – and don’t know what’s yet to come. By accessing resources available to them in the Farm Bill, connecting with others in the state that can help provide the hay they need to feed their cattle, and learning more about additional tools that can help provide relief, we can make sure all of our producers weather this drought together.

Always great to spend time in Casselton, especially when I get to see Casselton Fire Chief Tim McLean. Chief McLean and I sat down for lunch with folks from the community to talk about the challenges they face with a growing population. But Casselton is strong and resilient, like so many small towns in our state, and Casselton demonstrated that when folks across the community banded together after an oil train derailed near town in December 2013. After the derailment I got to know Chief McLean as I wrote my RESPONSE Act – legislation to make sure local and volunteer responders have the tools they need to safely protect their communities. That bill has been signed into law, and I’m working to make sure it’s implemented so brave first responders like Chief McLean – and communities like Casselton – remain strong and safe.

Wonderful to visit to the new North Dakota National Guard Maintenance Facility in Valley City. The new 45,000 square foot facility is a huge upgrade from the previous 3,230 square foot space. With all that extra room, our dedicated servicemembers will be able to support maintenance for a whopping 360 combat and tactical vehicles – boosting its ability to perform more maintenance in-state, and cut down on vehicle maintenance turnaround times. It’s great news our ND National Guard personnel will be supported by a facility expected to last at least half a century, and I’ll keep fighting for the resources and tools they need to keep our communities safe for many more years to come.

Families, individuals, and organizations who go above and beyond to improve the lives of foster and adoptive children are incredibly selfless and play a critical role in our communities. That’s why each year I look forward to selecting an Angel in Adoption to recognize one of the many North Dakotans who are willing to open their hearts and homes to children in need. I encourage North Dakotans to nominate folks that are deserving this recognition here: 1.usa.gov/1MoRQbm and the deadline is July 11, 2017.

Joined the North Dakota congressional delegation to call on USDA Secretary Perdue to allow emergency haying of Conservation Reserve Program acres to help North Dakota ranchers who are facing early season drought conditions. The drought is hitting North Dakota ranchers hard – with many are being forced to decide if they should sell valuable assets of the livestock operations. This has a long-term impact on the state’s livestock industry and we must do everything we can to support our producers. Click here to view my new webpage with state and federal resources to help folks monitor and mitigate the impacts of the drought: http://bit.ly/2s9UksI

Through the Community Service Block Grants – which the president’s budget would eliminate – more than 15,000 low-income North Dakotans were able to maintain an independent living situation. Nearly 22,000 low-income folks received help to get a job, obtain an increase in income, or achieve a livable wage. And overall, CSBG funding served more than 48,000 North Dakotans across the state – including almost 12,000 children, 8,000 people with disabilities, 11,000 seniors, and more than 13,000 people who lacked health insurance. Just because this federal funding would disappear doesn’t mean that these folks will too. I’ll work to make sure Congress uses an even-handed approach to the budget process that doesn’t hurt those who are most vulnerable.

In my newest episode of my podcast, ‘The Hotdish,’ I spoke with Dr. Mary Wakefield, former Deputy Secretary of HHS, and Georgetown University professor Sabrina Corlette, a health insurance expert, to reinforce how the Republican health care overhaul would hurt North Dakota. Right now, a handful of senators are negotiating a backroom deal—with no plans for a public hearing—to dramatically alter our health care system. That’s no way to govern, and if the proposal is anything like the bill the House passed, it would rip coverage from 28,000 North Dakotans. I hope folks listen to my podcast on iTunes (http://apple.co/2tKOSKQ) or SoundCloud (http://bit.ly/2sQogvz) to better understand what is happening with health care in America.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Great news that after months of pushing the Bureau of Reclamation on the importance of strong investments in water system improvements, many of our rural towns will get the boost they need to stay connected with water supplies built to last generations from now. North Dakota received the highest investment of any other state – receiving a total of $24.4 million in federal funding. As a small-town girl from Mantador, I come to the Senate every day with rural America on my mind, and I’m committed to making sure no community – from Petersburg or LaMoure to Cooperstown or New England – is left behind.

Don’t miss this article in the Fargo Forum about how the Republican bill that the U.S. House of Representatives passed and the bill just 13 U.S. senators are drafting in secret to could hurt the health care of North Dakotans across our state. The bill the House passed is immoral. It would rip Medicaid away from individuals and children with disabilities, seniors, and low-income families. It could make health care costs skyrocket for those with preexisting conditions like cancer or asthma. It would take away coverage of opioid abuse treatment for many North Dakotans. We need to address health care in this country and help make it better for families – but this bill cannot be the direction we go. Instead, we must stand up for North Dakota families so they can get accessible, affordable health care.

This Valley News Live story highlights my newest episode of my podcast, ‘The Hotdish,’ where I talk with health care experts about how the Republican health care bill would hurt North Dakotans. Taking away Medicaid, lifetime caps, and coverage for pre-existing conditions would hurt thousands of North Dakotans and their families – and that’s what the bill that passed in the U.S. House of Representatives would do. And just like the bill in the U.S. House, the bill in the U.S. Senate is being written behind closed doors with no input or transparency – this is not how a democracy works. The Republican health care bill that passed in the U.S. House of Representatives is immoral and would hurt thousands of North Dakotans who rely on Medicaid, have pre-existing conditions, or even chronic health issues that need constant care. Jennifer Restemayer and her daughter Allison from West Fargo are two of the many North Dakotans that I’ve heard from who are worried about the Republican health care bill would impact them.   When Allison was almost two years old, she was diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder. Allison’s parents were told she would become severely mentally delayed by age three, and that she would likely pass away by 10 years old. Over the past several years, Allison has been able to get a new – very expensive -- therapy that has helped slow the progression of her disorder. Because there are currently no longer lifetime limits on coverage, Allison’s family has been able to afford this treatment. Today, Allison is 16 years old.   The Republican health care bill would put in place lifetime maximums, could make it harder or unaffordable for those with pre-existing conditions get health insurance, and cut Medicaid – all of which would unfairly impact the Restemayers.   Just as the House bill was crafted and pushed through behind closed doors, we’re now seeing the same thing happening in the U.S. Senate. Just 13 senators are drafting a bill to revamp the health care system, but they won’t allow other senators or the public to see it. They won’t even hold hearings on it. For folks like Jennifer and Allison, health care isn’t about politics and secret back-room deals, it’s about life or death.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

This story is heart-breaking—and it reinforces that we should never go back to a time when folks with pre-existing conditions like asthma, diabetes, and cancer couldn’t afford health coverage. Watch National Farmers Union President Roger Johnson, a former North Dakota agriculture commissioner, tell the story of Tina, a farmer who used to be unable to afford insurance because of a pre-existing condition. When Tina was diagnosed with a brain tumor, she fortunately survived—but was saddled with $187,000 in hospital bills that her family had to pay out of pocket. The health care reform law isn’t perfect and it needs to be fixed, but it's helped folks like Tina get healthy and get insured. Tina is beside herself today because if the Republican health care bill passes, folks with pre-existing conditions like her could again be charged rates so high they can’t afford insurance. We can’t to go back to those days, and Tina’s story makes it clear how much farm and ranch families would suffer—especially when two in three farmers has a pre-existing condition.

Great to visit with Hankinson’s very own Gavin Kratcha, the 2017 champion of North Dakota’s annual You Be The Chemist Challenge, and his family. Gavin was one of just 42 students from a pool of 55,000 middle schoolers to participate in this year’s national competition in Washington, D.C. The Peace Garden State depends on the next generation of North Dakota scientists and engineers like Gavin to lead the cutting-edge research and innovation that is so crucial to the prosperity of our state. Congrats, Gavin!

National Farmers Union President Roger Johnson is right—we need to fix the pieces of the health care reform law that are broken, not throw out what’s working for rural communities and family farmers. Farmers and ranchers are facing a tough economy, but the bill Congress is considering would make matters worse by threatening the solvency of rural hospitals and leaving young farmers uninsured. The bill the U.S. House of Representatives passed would rip away coverage from 30,000 in North Dakota, including farm and ranch families. Without insurance, an illness in the family can spell disaster—and that’s especially true for farmers and ranchers. Ripping away coverage from those families is unacceptable, and I’ll never vote for a bill that makes it harder for rural communities to get the affordable health care they need.

There’s a special place in heaven for the families who open their hearts and homes to foster and adoptive children and give them a home filled with love and support. Each year, I look forward to selecting an Angel in Adoption to share the great work they do to improve the lives of foster and adoptive kids and raise awareness about the positive and life-changing impact folks can make on these children to encourage more to open their homes. If you know someone who is deserving of this recognition, I hope you’ll nominate them to be Angels in Adoption before July 11, 2017. Click here to fill out the form:  1.usa.gov/1MoRQbm

If the House bill to overhaul the health care system was a train speeding towards a bridge-less ravine, the Senate bill released today may have slowed the train down but does nothing to stop the passengers from certain calamity ahead. After drafting a bill in secret to overhaul our country’s health care system, the best Senate Republicans could come up with is a bill that looks very similar to the cruel bill the U.S. House of Representatives passed. Both bills are downright bad for North Dakota. Over the past several decades and in the last few months, I’ve spoken with far too many parents of children with disabilities, individuals with health challenges like cancer or diabetes, and North Dakotans including the elderly and single parents who struggle every day to get the affordable care they deserve. It’s because of them that I refuse to give any credence to bills that would purposely seek to take their health coverage away or make it unaffordable. That isn’t who we are as a country. And it isn’t who I am as a North Dakotan.  Just like the House bill, the Senate bill would put at risk the more than 90,000 North Dakotans on Medicaid – individuals and children with disabilities, seniors, and low-income families – by ending Medicaid expansion and slashing traditional Medicaid – a proven, cost effective, life-saving program – even more than the House bill would. It would still disproportionately hurt rural communities and close rural hospitals and clinics across our state. It would still prevent many North Dakotans from affording treatment for opioid abuse. It would still allow insurance companies to give older, sicker individuals plans with minimal coverage, effectively forcing them to pay out of pocket for their health care which many can’t afford. And it would still do all of this damage while giving a tax cut to the wealthiest Americans.   We need to improve our health care system. I’ve been saying this for years. In 2013, I put together a health care advisory board made up of health care leaders in North Dakota to have that discussion. Over the past three and a half years, I’ve offered many improvements to make the health reform law work better for families and businesses. We should work together and have this important conversation in a bipartisan way, out in the open for all to see and hear. Unfortunately, the opposite of that is what has come out of both the House and Senate. North Dakota deserves better.

The Economic Development Administration promotes innovation and competitiveness at the state and local levels through strategic federal investments. Since 2009, the EDA has invested more than $34 million in North Dakota, including funding to support a Jobs Accelerator at United Tribes Technical College, infrastructure projects in Northwood, and more. The EDA investments in North Dakota have led to more than $478 million in private investments and created nearly 1,300 jobs. The president’s budget would cut the entire EDA – taking away a key tool that so many North Dakota communities use for projects to help spur growth. Eliminating this program is senseless. As Congress works to set the budget, I’ll fight to keep critical programs that our rural communities rely on.

Growing up in Mantador, my mom was a school cook who helped make sure every child had a good, nutritious meal at our small rural school – and that’s not something any North Dakota student should miss out on, no matter how rural or cash-strapped their school district might be. That’s why today I re-introduced my bipartisan bill with Republican U.S. Senator Susan Collins from Maine that would help North Dakota schools with the resources and equipment they need to provide nutritious meals and help their students better learn and grow. In North Dakota, more than one-third of the school districts need kitchen infrastructure changes to at least one of their schools to meet federal standards and reduce inefficiencies and costs, and this commonsense, bipartisan bill would better support those schools

Great news for folks across North Dakota and rural America that premium processing will resume for all H-1B petitions filed for medical doctors under the Conrad 30 program – which I pushed for with U.S. Senators Amy Klobuchar (D-MN) and Susan Collins (R-ME). The Conrad 30 program has helped doctors from other countries who have been trained at our top notch universities and medical schools to stay here and serve those in rural areas and in other communities that struggle to recruit and retain an adequate physician workforce. We need to enable more doctors to use this program to practice in rural areas and work to make this program permanent to help support quality care in rural areas.

You can’t put a few band-aids on a bad bill and think North Dakotans won’t feel the pain. The CBO report that came out today on the Senate Republican health care bill reinforces that this bill is just as bad as the bill the House of Representatives passed as it would rip away health care from 22 million Americans by 2026. That isn’t improvement. Just like the House bill, the biggest savings would come from severe cuts to Medicaid which is a cruel joke to the 90,000 North Dakotans who rely on this lifesaving program for affordable, quality care. North Dakotans have had their voices heard – individuals with pre-existing conditions like cancer or asthma, parents of children with disabilities on Medicaid, adults with elderly parents in nursing homes, farmers and those in rural communities who rely on rural hospitals, and those receiving treatment for opioid abuse have all stood up to oppose this bill and explain the real life consequences.   This bill is a not-so-veiled attempt to provide tax cuts for the wealthiest individuals at the expense of rural communities like those across our state. Those who voted for the House bill should be held accountable for such a heartless decision, and those considering voting for the Senate bill should think about the families all across the country who would be directly impacted by their votes. We need to reform our health care system as I’ve been saying for years. But this bill isn’t the way to do it. Instead, let’s have an honest, meaningful, transparent, and bipartisan conversation about health care. Congress is supposed to work for the American people. Instead this bill, which was crafted in secret, would destroy the lives of families across our state and country who are just trying to keep their children, parents, and spouses healthy. They deserve better.

I’ve heard from hundreds of North Dakotans about how they rely on programs like Medicaid to keep their children, parents, or spouses healthy. More than 90,000 North Dakotans -- including children and individuals with disabilities, seniors, and low-income families -- across the state rely on Medicaid to help make ends meet or provide supplemental insurance. The Republican health care bill in the U.S. Senate would slash funding for Medicaid by 26% in 2026. This bill is a not-so-veiled attempt to provide tax cuts for the wealthiest individuals on the backs of folks like Emerie and her family from Bismarck.   At two months old, Emerie had her first set of seizures and was diagnosed with a rare neurological condition. Emerie is on Medicaid which provides affordable, quality health care.  Medicaid enables Emerie's family to afford her hospital stays, at home care, and therapy. It’s because of access to Medicaid that the Thoms have been able to stay in their home and keep their jobs.  Families like the Thom’s don’t care about scoring political points, they care about making sure their little girl gets the care she needs and that they can afford to give her and the rest of their family a good life.  Congress is supposed to work for the American people. Instead this bill, which was crafted in secret, would destroy the lives of families across our state and country who are just trying to keep their children, parents, and spouses healthy. They deserve better.

Earlier today, I talked about how the Senate Republican health care bill would hurt North Dakota and rural America with Jim Shaw on WDAY radio. After releasing the bill to the public late last week and receiving an estimate from the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office yesterday on how it will impact Americans, the Senate Republicans have now delayed the vote on their health care bill. This is good news, but the fight is far from over. Under the Senate Republican health care bill, 22 million Americans would lose health care by 2026, including more than 31,000 North Dakotans. It would disproportionately shift the cost to older Americans who tend to live in rural communities. On average, North Dakotans would see their premiums increase by 76% under the Senate bill.  Medicaid would be slashed by 26% in 2016 – a cruel move to the 90,000 North Dakota seniors, individuals and children with disabilities, and low-income families who rely on the program for affordable, quality care. We must continue to fight to protect access to health care.

Ranae Byre from Burlington is currently in the fight against stage 4 breast cancer. She has days when she feels good, and days when she doesn’t. Yesterday was one of the days she didn’t. But regardless, she was in Washington, DC on Capitol Hill to advocate against the Senate Republican health care bill because it was too important to be here and have her voice heard. Despite receiving regular treatments since 2009, Ranae – a mother of three – is still working and receives health care through her employer. But she knows that she won’t be able to work forever, and that’s when her fear sets in about the Republican health care proposals. Ranae is worried that she won’t be able to get health insurance because of her pre-existing condition – or that without access to Medicaid or subsides in the exchange, she’ll be charged so much that she and her family won’t be able to afford it. When Ranae was diagnosed in 2009, her youngest son was in kindergarten and her goal was to see him graduate from high school – which happens to be this year. As Ranae says, health care shouldn’t be a partisan issue, it’s a people issue, and it’s a basic needs issue. The Senate Republicans delaying the vote on their health care bill this week is good news, but our fight to make sure we don’t pull the rug out from under folks like Ranae is far from over.

Study after study shows that kids who eat right and eat well do better in school, and our bill would help make sure every child has a good, nutritious meal – not matter how rural or cash-strapped their school districts might be.

North Korea launching an intercontinental ballistic missile potentially capable of reaching the United States drives home what we’ve long known: North Korea’s provocative and destabilizing behavior is one of the most critical security challenges facing the United States.  North Korea’s ability to strike the U.S. homeland and efforts to continue developing its ballistic missile capability reinforce that addressing this threat through tough, smart national security strategies—which I’ve been calling for—must be an urgent national security priority. Our best defense against a nuclear-armed North Korea remains a credible nuclear deterrent—and that means our ICBMs and our bombers, like those at Minot Air Force Base, as well as sea-launched ballistic missiles. Working with the administration and Congress, I’m committed to bolstering our military’s deterrent and defensive capabilities, deepening our alliances in East Asia, and making sure our nation’s most capable diplomats stand ready to manage the complex dynamics North Korea’s irresponsible behavior has unleashed.

Like thousands of families across North Dakota, Matthew and Jenny in Williston use Medicaid to make sure that their son with developmental disabilities can get the care he needs. Matthew and Jenny are lucky because they have good insurance through Jenny’s work, but they know that if the cuts to Medicaid proposed in the Senate Republican health care bill were put in place, that many families would have to choose between getting care for their loved one or losing their house or job. This is immoral. Last week I met with folks in Bowman, Hazen, and Bismarck to talk about how the Senate Republican health care bill would make health care more expensive for families, put rural hospitals across the state – who are already operating on thin margins – in jeopardy, and how the proposed changes to Medicaid would devastate the 90,000 North Dakotans who rely on this lifesaving program. I talked with so many families like Matthew and Jenny who know that making quality health care affordable and accessible is something we all deserve. The fight continues to make sure we stop this bill and hearing about the potential impacts from folks across the state and hearing from folks like Matthew and Jenny make me eager to get back to Washington and make sure their voice is heard.

We will never be able to repay our veterans for their service to our country, but we need to do everything we can to support them when they return. That’s why I’m proud to announce that a bipartisan bill I cosponsored was signed into law to make sure veterans can find great jobs in law enforcement—helping protect our communities even after they take off the uniform. When our veterans transition to civilian life, it’s our duty to make sure they have every opportunity to put the skills they picked up serving our country to good use. This law will help accomplish that goal by making sure veterans are prioritized in hiring and training at agencies that receive federal funds through the Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) program. State and local law enforcement agencies will also benefit, because highly-trained veterans are well prepared with the skills they need to keep our communities safe.

Today USDA announced that it will allow insurers to give ranchers impacted by the drought who have experienced financial losses due to early livestock losses to waive the Livestock Risk Protection requirement for 30-days. Farmers and ranchers across our state have been through the ringer when it comes to the drought – struggling to find feed or forage, many have been forced to take the financial hit of selling their livestock much sooner than they otherwise would have. These are the real challenges ranchers in western North Dakota told me about when I visited with them in Bowman last week, and it’s because of them that I’ve been banging on Secretary Perdue’s door to make sure every tool in the USDA toolbox is available to help them get through, and it’s great news that he has been so responsive.

Coal provides one-third of electricity in the U.S. and is – and will continue to be – an important part to our national and global energy mix. That’s why today, I’ve teamed up with U.S. Senators Sheldon Whitehouse (D-RI) and Shelley Moore Capito (R-WV) to lead a broad bipartisan group of senators to reintroduce the FUTURE Act - our legislation to extend and expand the 45Q tax credit. By doing so, this bill would encourage technological innovation that reduces CO2 emissions and supports coal as a part of a diverse energy mix. Nothing gets done in Congress unless all sides sit down, get serious, and find common ground—and that’s what we did to rally such a broad coalition of senators, coal companies, and environmental groups in support of our bill. Even in these partisan times, bipartisanship and commonsense can prevail – and our bill reinforces that. Watch live as we announce this bill, along with organizations from across the energy spectrum.

For too long, coal has been divisive. But today I reintroduced the FUTURE Act with U.S. Senators Sheldon Whitehouse (D-RI) and Shelley Moore Capito (R-WV). The FUTURE Act is a bipartisan bill that would extend and expand the 45Q tax credit and spur innovation and investment in clean coal technologies that brought together a strong bipartisan group of senators – as well as coal companies and environmental groups. This bill is proof that it is possible to find a realistic path forward when commonsense and the desire to get things done is at the forefront. Through smart investments, the FUTURE Act will encourage companies to use CO2 in enhanced oil recovery and other settings, and encourage U.S. leadership in carbon capture utilization technologies, while reducing emissions. The divisive partisanship on display during the health care debate has led to most Americans to believe that Congress cannot get things done or work together. But the truth is that that’s not the case – bipartisanship can happen if senators park the ideology at the door, and come to the table ready to find common ground. That’s what I did last week when I reintroduced my FUTURE Act – a broad bipartisan bill that brought together some of the most vocal advocates for action on climate change and some of the most vocal advocates in support of coal. We found a way to bring folks together – both senators and organizations – to find that sweet spot where we can all agree. And this bill can make a difference for coal because it wasn’t inspired by rhetoric or partisanship—it was inspired by a drive to get results. I believe we can do the same for health care, and I keep fighting for a compromise, bipartisan solution to help improve health care for North Dakota families.

At a recent Senate committee hearing, I reinforced the importance of maintaining and strengthening USDA programs that support North Dakota agricultural exports.
