As we gear up for the next Farm Bill, I’ll fight to defend those export promotion and market access programs—particularly as the administration proposes cuts to export promotion programs in the budget, just when farmers and ranchers need them most to make ends meet amid drought and a tough farm economy. https://goo.gl/pYEhH8

Today called on leaders on the U.S. Senate Committee on Appropriations to strengthen and expand the ELAP program to include assistance for transporting hay and livestock, and not just water. Our farmers and ranchers are doing their best to keep pushing through the most severe drought our state has seen in decades – but often the financial costs that pile up from transporting resources like hay and livestock can prove too heavy a lift. Programs like ELAP help ease the burden of transporting water – but when it comes to hauling hay and livestock, farmers and ranchers are on their own. By expanding the program to include hay and livestock, we can make sure that we’re providing the comprehensive tools and resources farmers and ranchers need during the drought.

ICYMI – on Squawk Box this morning, I made the case for why Congress needs to bury the political hatchet, sit down, work together, and find commonsense solutions to improve our health care system. I’ve long said that there are good pieces of the current health reform law and pieces that need to be fixed. And since I’ve joined the U.S. Senate, I’ve been working to do that. Time for Congress to start working together to do our job.

Helped lead a call to action in the U.S. Senate to fight against efforts in the Republican health care bill that would rip away access to health care for Native Americans living on tribal lands. This is a discussion that hasn’t been widely addressed, and I’m working to change that. When we talk about health care in Indian Country, we’re talking about a sacred trust obligation, and this Republican health care bill would shatter that promise. Medicaid is a lifeline for families in Indian Country as across North Dakota, 54% of Native children relied on Medicaid for health coverage in 2015. But the Republican bill would slash Medicaid – a program that provides health care for many Native Americans, as well as many others across our state including children with disabilities, seniors in nursing homes, and low-income families in rural communities. We must make sure all of these individuals and children can continue to get affordable, quality care through Medicaid.

I’ll continue to hold the U.S. Postal Service accountable and makes sure all North Dakotans are able to get their mail, packages, and medicine on time.

Since I heard firsthand from ranchers in Bowman a few weeks ago about the challenges they face because of the drought, I’ve been in high-gear to do everything I can to provide relief and support. That’s why it’s great news that after calling on USDA, they’ve provided additional relief by opening up more than 39% of the 40% remaining CRP acres so ranchers can get hay close to home. In addition, the Senate Committee on Appropriations approved my request to expand disaster cost reimbursements for farmers and ranchers. And just today after my push, USDA announced that it will provide more staff to the FSA offices in McHenry, Mountrail, Bowman, Golden Valley, Hettinger, and Stark counties – these folks should be deployed in the next week. I consistently hear high praises from farmers in ranchers about the FSA staff that helps them consider their options, but in this severe drought, too many North Dakota offices are understaffed, or have their hands tied in terms of the help they’re able to offer. Secretary Perdue’s quick actions to help get farmers and ranchers assistance reinforce why he is the right person for the job, and I look forward to continuing to work with him to make more comprehensive, permanent improvements to the drought resources our farmers need now.

I’m calling on my colleagues in the Senate to today, when we vote on a Republican health care bill, put aside petty partisan politics and remember how critical health care is for millions of folks across the country – folks like Anthony Arnold from Grand Forks. Anthony was born with cerebral palsy and for his entire life has needed physical, occupational, and speech therapies. In addition, Anthony needs wheelchairs, communication devices, walkers, and braces. Anthony recently was able to get his own health insurance plan – a day he describes as the happiest day of his adult life. The Republican health care bills being drafted in back rooms and pushed through Congress without hearings or debate would hurt millions of Americans. We owe it to folks like Anthony to work across the aisle, do what’s right, and find commonsense solutions that will fix our current health care system.

Today was a vote that will go down in history. Republicans in the U.S. Senate knowingly voted to strip away health care for 23 million Americans, including children with disabilities, seniors in nursing homes, those in rural communities who live far from hospitals or doctors, and individuals seeking treatment for opioid abuse. We absolutely need to improve the current health care system – but this bill isn’t the way to do it. Pushing through a bill without even talking with those on the other side of the aisle isn’t the way to do it. And advancing a bill that is opposed by hundreds of organizations including AARP, the North Dakota Medical Association, and the North Dakota Hospital Association isn’t the way to do it. As the Senate now considers this bill, I hope those who supported it closely consider what the impact of this bill would mean for families, children, and seniors in their states. I can’t support this bill because I care too much about North Dakotans. I want to make sure they are able to get health care for their loved ones, and not have it ripped away when it’s needed most. As I’ve long been calling for, Congress needs to work together across party lines to seek real, honest, transparent, bipartisan reforms to our health care system so it works better for families. I want to have that conversation and I hope Republicans will join me. Congress needs to talk about solving problems – not who to blame.

U.S. Senate appropriators heeded the call I led with a diverse group of 15 Democratic senators to maintain strong funding for research and development of carbon capture, utilization, and storage techniques. If we’re serious about committing to a realistic all-of-the-above energy plan that includes a viable future for coal and coal jobs, we need to make sure the federal resources are there to help make that goal possible. This move is especially important after the president’s budget called for slashing research and development programs on critical CCUS technologies by more than half. Creating a viable future for coal is important for North Dakota and our country, which is why I’ll continue my work across the aisle to find commonsense, bipartisan solutions that invest in innovative technologies.

Today the president announced via Twitter that transgender Americans will be banned from serving in the U.S. military. We need to honor – not shame – the men and women who put their lives on the line for the country they love, because every veteran and member of the military is owed our utmost respect for their service and sacrifice. If a servicemember can do the job and is willing, they should be able to serve – and they should be able to be open about who they are. It’s deeply unfortunate the president chose to announce this divisive news in an abbreviated and cavalier manner via social media, potentially impacting thousands of transgender servicemembers currently serving around the world. Decisions about military force posture and readiness are matters of life and death that should be among the most seriously considered by a president, and motivated by the best military judgment of the armed forces – not by politics.   It’s also troubling that we could see more action. News reports have said the U.S. Justice Department is preparing to undercut existing anti-discrimination protections for LGBTQ Americans. This action would roll back many of the important steps we have made to stop discrimination. We cannot allow discrimination of any form – not in schools, places of business, or our communities.

Had a great discussion today with the senior military official responsible for the Asia-Pacific region, Admiral Harry Harris Jr. Admiral Harris and I focused on North Korea’s continued development of an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) that could strike the U.S. homeland and the need to address this threat through tough, smart national security strategies. As I reinforced to Admiral Harris when we first met last fall during my official Senate fact-finding trip examining the nation’s missile defense capabilities, the best defense against a nuclear-armed North Korea remains a credible nuclear deterrent. And that means supporting the ICBMs and bombers at places like Minot Air Force Base. We also discussed how to manage competition with China and the importance of all elements of national power, including trade and diplomacy, in strengthening our security in the Asia-Pacific region. Committed and dedicated military members like Admiral Harris and his team, and the folks at Grand Forks and Minot Air Force Bases are essential to maintaining strong national security strategies and I appreciate all of their hard work and sacrifice.

Rural hospitals in North Dakota and across the country are already running on a thin margin to provide quality and comprehensive health care close to home. But the Republican health care bill that the U.S. Senate is debating right now would put their services in jeopardy by threatening to take away additional funding and gutting programs that help keep rural hospital doors open. This KMOT-TV story highlights the critical role rural hospitals play across North Dakota and that unfortunately, 33% of them are vulnerable to closure. Where you live shouldn’t impact your access to or quality of health care. I’ll push for proposals that will help keep these hospitals open so they can continue providing top-notch service in their communities.

Far too often in Congress, politics dictates legislation, and it needs to stop. The bill the Senate voted on tonight was a bad bill. I could not support a bill that was crafted behind closed doors and would have ripped health care away from tens of thousands of North Dakotans or made it unaffordable. History will remember where each of us stood during this vote. We should be here to do what is best for the American people. Many hoped this bill would pass for political reasons, instead it failed for the right reason – because it would have hurt our neighbors and communities. Perhaps the failure of this bill is a long overdue wake up call to those on both sides of the aisle that to accomplish results, members of Congress truly need to work together and put partisan politics aside. Republicans and Democrats should be able to join together to pass real, transparent, bipartisan reforms to improve health care for families, as I’ve been working to accomplish. This conversation is long overdue. For years I’ve said the health reform law isn’t perfect, no law ever is. But we can make it work better through needed reforms, and I have many ideas that I’ll keep offering. I’m hopeful there is now an opening for progress. My office door remains wide open.

Today is Startup Day and an opportunity to acknowledge the talented entrepreneurs in North Dakota who have helped put our state on the map for innovation. According to the Kaufman Foundation, North Dakota is the state with the third highest startup activity in the country – proving that startups aren’t just in New York or California. After bringing the former Small Business Administrator to North Dakota for the first U.S. Senate Committee on Small Business committee hearing in 2015, I got to work to address some of the challenges local innovators said they had – the main one being early state funding. That’s what led to my SEED Act – a bill that would help startups in rural states turn ideas into action by giving them access to the federal funding they need. #StartupDay

Worked across the aisle to introduce a bipartisan bill that would make sure websites that knowingly facilitate sex trafficking online can be held accountable for their role in this most hideous form of modern day slavery. For too long, websites like Backpage have profited from knowingly facilitating the sex trafficking of minors and others through the use of their online platform – in many instances, helping traffickers skirt law enforcement and their own standards to advertise minors for sex. And what’s worse: they’ve been able to continue doing this without penalty by claiming protection under the First Amendment. That’s a disgusting and cowardly invocation of one of our nation’s most cherished freedoms – neither the First Amendment nor the Communications Decency Act was written to shield those who help enslave and sell children for sex. It’s past time to hold websites that make money from sex trafficking accountable, just as our laws already do for traffickers, for the enslavement and abuse of men, women, and even children – who have been reportedly trafficked at a near 850 percent increase since 2010 largely because of the anonymity internet sales provide – and our bipartisan bill would work to do that by cracking down on these horrific crimes online.

That will make sure folks can enjoy the great outdoors in our state for generations.

In 2015, I was honored to present local veteran, former prisoner of war and member of the Spirit Lake Sioux Tribe, Corporal Andrew Shaw, with his Purple Heart. Cpl. Shaw was taken prisoner after North Korea won the Battle of Chochiwon. He marched through mountains and snow, suffering malnourishment and diseases. Once in Seoul, Korea, Cpl. Shaw was a Prisoner of War for 37 months and was finally released in August of 1953.   Today on #PurpleHeartDay, I hope folks thank and remember the sacrifice of folks like Corporal Andrew Shaw who bravely served our country. Throughout history, North Dakotans have stepped up time and time again to serve our country by leaving their families and loved ones to put themselves in harm’s way. Honoring American heroes who fought for the freedom for future generations is an intrinsic part of making sure we continue to thank those who served. I’m deeply committed to making sure that the brave folks who put their lives on the line receive the recognition, support, and resources they earned. Thank you to all those who have served our nation and their families.

A recent Government Accountability Office report on human trafficking in Indian Country confirms what I and others who work closely with tribal communities have long known – that there is a staggering lack of reporting, and therefore an incomplete understanding of the number of Native American human trafficking victims. It’s unacceptable that federal agencies who control more than 50 federal grant programs to help protect victims don’t require reporting on the ground. For years I’ve been working to shine a light on traffickers who exploit Native women and children because they know they can escape law enforcement’s attention, starting with a Senate hearing back in 2013. That’s why the Democratic members of the U.S. Senate Committee on Indian Affairs and I spoke with the authors of the government report and a Minnesota provider of services to Indian women victims to hear about how we can use these reports to sharpen the federal government’s response and focus on the true need that exists in Indian Country and among the larger Native American community.

This story I shared over a year ago at a press conference about a mother’s desperate plea for her daughter who is addicted to opioids to get arrested so she can get treatment is one of the many stories I’ve heard from folks across our state. Folks who are trying desperately to save their loved ones but run into a brick wall when they seek out affordable, quality treatment. That’s not the way it should be in America. And that’s why I’ve been working for more than a year to bring community leaders together during six meetings across the state to discuss a comprehensive strategy that can combat the opioid epidemic. I have also been working on this legislatively by helping pass a bill that would use existing funds to provide more tools for first responders, law enforcement, and educators responding to the crisis. In addition to that bill – which is now law – I’m also pushing for my LifeBOAT Act, which would help communities get the funding they need for addiction services, treatment programs & recovery efforts they need to adequately meet demand. This story doesn’t have to be the reality in our communities, and if we come together to find commonsense solutions, we can change it.  https://goo.gl/BEPUmo

Great to join Truckers Against Trafficking in Bismarck today to talk about how we need a community response to combat human trafficking. TAT has played an important role to help educate truckers on how to recognize and respond to instances of human trafficking. The only way to stop these horrific crimes is by building a network among health care professionals, law enforcement, local leaders, and all across North Dakota’s communities to make sure we can stop these horrific crimes from happening in our backyards. Truckers Against Trafficking has taken a key role in helping make that possible by providing North Dakota truckers with the information and resources they need to identify potential crimes and notify law enforcement.

Great to join folks at United Lutheran Church’s Neighborhood Summer Lunch Program in Grand Forks today – a community driven and volunteer-run program that provides nutritious lunches for low-income children. North Dakota’s cities and town are filled with folks who help build strong communities by volunteering their time and money to provide important service like summer meals. The U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Summer Food Service Program provides meals for children during summer months. Unfortunately, the funding does not always last for the entire summer. To make up for the three week gap in funds at the end of the summer, the Grand Forks community through United Lutheran Church was able to raise funds to make sure these children have meals that fuel them through their summer activities. For some children, the summer lunch programs may provide the only meal a child eats that day. This program is a wonderful example of a community coming together to fill a need.

As the U.S., Mexico, and Canada today begin renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), it’s essential that farmers and ranchers are still able to export their products abroad. Trade is essential for agriculture states like North Dakota. If farm workers can’t export their products, their farms and businesses aren’t able to function and their jobs disappear. Farm communities are already struggling with low commodity prices and drought, and on top of that, many have already lost business because of rising tensions with top trading partners. The federal government needs to step in to support our farmers and ranchers, not pull the rug out from under them. I’ve stressed this over and over to USDA Secretary Perdue and U.S. Trade Representative Lighthizer to reinforce the concerns of North Dakota farmers and ranchers. We need to and can support American workers and level the playing field for manufacturing jobs, but it must not come at the expense of farm jobs. When 95 percent of consumers live outside the U.S., if we aren’t exporting, we’re losing. Check out an op-ed I wrote about this issue back in March.

ICYMI – this Grand Forks Herald article takes a look at the current state of human trafficking in North Dakota, how local organizations, law enforcement, and communities have come together to improve prevention and detection methods, and new laws that help protect victims. Every day in the U.S. Senate I wake up thinking about how I can fight better and harder for rural America – and as the heartbeat of rural communities, North Dakota workers must be at the forefront of any tax reform bill. When a sitting president visits North Dakota, that’s a welcome opportunity for our state and a chance for us to highlight North Dakota’s priorities. It was good for our state that President Trump came to Mandan today to hear those priorities firsthand. When I look to the future of North Dakota’s economy, I think about the working families like mine in small, rural towns like Mantador where I grew up. Today President Trump spoke about his priorities for tax reform, and it’s encouraging he committed to promoting American workers as key to any tax reform policy. But, as North Dakota’s former Tax Commissioner, I know the devil is in the details of any reform plan as tax codes are complex, and we need to know what those details are. I’ve long said that I’m open to working with Republicans and Democrats on comprehensive, permanent tax reform that promotes North Dakotans during their working years as well as protects their dignity in their retirement, and I intend to keep working with both sides of the aisle to see if we can come up with a tax reform plan that works for North Dakota workers and retirees.

On this horrific day 16 years ago, first responders and emergency workers ran up into World Trade Center towers that were collapsing around them. Despite being hurt and panicked, they offered protection, support, and put their lives on the line to fulfil their duty. And in the months that followed, these folks continued to risk their lives searching for survivors at a severely hazardous site. These are real American heroes. But for many of the first responders who went to Ground Zero, their selfless work left them with debilitating disease and cancers. Folks like Raymond Pfeifer, who died from cancer that he got after months of searching for survivors in the rubble, and who I was honored to meet. In 2015, Congress finally passed a law that extended health care benefits to survivors and first responders from that day. We will never forget the memories of those we lost that day and will always be grateful for the brave men and women who kept us safe and continue to put their lives on the line each and every day. #NeverForget

Great to speak with tribal leaders from across the country today at the National Congress of American Indian Unity Days in Washington, D.C. about the three foundational pieces of Indian Country that we need to work on -- improving access to quality and affordable health care, addressing the housing crisis head on, and making sure Native youth have access to quality education. We’ve been able to make some progress on these issues – like my bill to stand up for Native youth being signed into law last year – but there’s still a long way to go. As I reinforced to this group today, I’ll continue to be a fierce advocate for improving conditions in Indian Country and making sure the federal government fulfills its trust and treaty obligations.

Tonight I joined a dinner at the White House with the president and a bipartisan group of senators to discuss tax reform because Any chance to talk with the president about issues important to North Dakota is an opportunity I welcome. We had a good discussion and I reinforced that any tax reform bill must support working families and family farmers so they aren’t burdened with debt and it must stand up for retirees who want to live their remaining years with dignity while also simplifying the tax code and lowering compliance burdens. As North Dakota’s former tax commissioner, I understand how much these issues directly impact North Dakota families, farmers, and workers – which is why any tax reform plan must be done with their best interest in mind. We still need to see more details about what this tax reform plan entails, and I look forward to reviewing them. It’s encouraging that this meeting included Republican and Democratic senators, as I’ve long said I want to work with those on both sides of the aisle on a comprehensive, permanent tax reform plan that works for North Dakota workers and retirees and helps grow the economy, and I hope these bipartisan discussions continue.

Today, Yvonne bravely shared her story at a U.S. Senate Committee hearing to reinforce the need for the bipartisan bill I helped introduce that would hold websites like Backpage accountable for its role to knowingly facilitate online sex trafficking.  Yvonne’s daughter, Desiree, was smart, beautiful, loved by all, and like all daughters – the light of her mother's life. Unfortunately, Desiree’s tragic story is shared by thousands of other young women and children who are preyed on online and sold for sex trafficking. This has to stop. My heart goes out to Yvonne and her family, and the countless others out there who have suffered the same unbearable loss. As Yvonne said today, we need to pass this bill not just for justice for Desiree, but for all the other Jane Does, and little girls to come who don’t have a voice.

Building on my work to help North Dakota’s first responders, today I introduced legislation that would open up more federal housing programs to volunteer first responders. This would help incentivize North Dakotans to volunteer and keep them in the force. Ask any fire chief from Williston to Valley City, and they’ll tell you the number of volunteers on their forces isn’t what it used to be – but it’s not for lack of folks who want to give back to their communities. When more families are having trouble finding affordable housing, it’s much harder to come up with money to put down roots in a community – causing volunteer fire departments to see an increase in the average age of volunteers and decrease in number of years served. This commonsense legislation aims to fix that.

Republicans in the U.S. Senate are – once again – trying to pass a bill that would hurt North Dakota families by increasing the costs of health care and ripping away support families rely on to afford coverage. The Graham-Cassidy bill would repeal tax credits that more than 17,000 North Dakotans rely on to make health insurance affordable. It’s also projected that if this bill were to pass, the number of uninsured North Dakotans would double by 2019. The discussion and debate about health care needs to stop being about politics and be about American families and children – those who will suffer under these horrible proposals, or who will have to choose between health care for their families or heating their homes this winter. North Dakotans deserve better than this. That’s why I’ll keep pushing back against terrible bills – like the Graham-Cassidy bill – and work across the aisle to find a bipartisan solution that will actually address the health care challenges in our country today.

Last time Republicans in the U.S. Senate tried to pass a health care bill that put politics over the health care of American families, North Dakotans spoke out – and we need to do the same now. The Graham-Cassidy bill is just as bad as previous health care proposals that Republicans tried to push through. This summer, Matthew Nelson from Williston shared how severe cuts to Medicaid would impact his son Graham and others like him. This bill reignites that concern and puts Medicaid funding – which a total of 90,000 North Dakotans rely on – on the chopping block yet again. Reach out to my office, let your voice be heard, we have to stop this horrible bill from passing the U.S Senate.

Here’s what is at stake under the Graham-Cassidy health care bill: If you have a pre-existing condition like asthma or diabetes, your health costs could skyrocket under this Republican bill. If you are on Medicaid, which is the case for many seniors and children with disabilities, you could lose affordable health coverage under this Republican bill. If you are over the age of 60 and are currently not penalized for your age, that could change under this Republican bill. If you currently qualify for a tax credit so your family can afford care, that would go away under this Republican bill. I’m asking North Dakotans to call, email, tweet, or post about how this bill would impact you and your family. We need your voices if we’re going to stop this horrible bill from passing in the U.S. Senate.  It was your voices that stopped the last Republican proposal from passing the U.S. Senate, and I’m confident you can make a difference again now.

From meetings with North Dakotans and through my Fix My Mail initiative, I’ve heard time and time again about the chronic mail challenges North Dakotans face in rural communities across our state. I’ll keep fighting for the lasting investments in critical programs like Essential Air Service – a program that helps support hundreds of jobs across our state and generate millions in our statewide economy – so that our state can continue to flourish for years to come.

ICYMI—This week in the U.S. Senate Committee on Indian Affairs, global anti-human trafficking advocate, Cindy McCain, and I spoke about two recent Government Accountability Office reports that revealed severe lapses among law enforcement in terms of reporting requirements of Native American human trafficking victims. For years, Cindy McCain and I have worked closely with tribal communities and experts on the ground that have told us about the severity of human trafficking crimes in Indian Country – from talks with tribal leaders and service providers in Fort Berthold in 2015, to our recent discussion with the authors of the GAO study that revealed the extent of this underreporting. It’s clear that the federal government can and must do a better job of tuning in to the true extent of the challenges that can endanger our most vulnerable in Indian Country. We’ll keep working to sound the alarm bells both on the ground and in the halls of Congress until every Native community is protected by the full extent of the law, and has the resources to stay safe from these hideous crimes.

The tragic killing of Savanna LaFontaine-Greywind is yet another call to action, which is why I’ve named this new bill in her memory. Today in Bismarck and Minot I made stops three and four on my tax reform listening tour to hear directly from North Dakotans about their priorities and concerns regarding the upcoming debate on tax reform. In meetings with small business owners, workers, families, and retirees, I laid out my priorities for tax reform: It must level the playing field for workers, families, and retirees. It must make it easier and less costly for families and businesses to file taxes. And it must grow the economy while being fiscally responsible. Honored to join U.S. Senator John Hoeven to present the French Legion of Honor award to Lynn Aas for his service in France in WWII. Lynn joined the military when the U.S. entered WWII and exceled in both his training and on the field. He was on the front lines in Belgium and Germany and did everything he could to protect our nation. Lynn received the Purple Heart after being injured in Germany and the Bronze Star for his efforts during battles around Bastogne and in the Ardennes during the harsh winter months. When Lynn returned to North Dakota, he continued his education at UND where he earned a law degree before working for the IRS for 10 years. Lynn's accomplishments and contributions to our state go all the way back to his involvement in the North Dakota Constitutional Convention of 1972, and include many terms in the state legislature, chairing organizations and helping promote North Dakota and the Minot area anyway he can. Retirement hasn’t slowed him down a bit – Lynn was a founding member of the weekly coffee group of retired community leaders called, “The Know-It-Alls.” Lynn's imprint on our country and state are embedded into its history and I’m grateful for the opportunity to help present him with this deserving honor today.

The administration’s decision to cut federal funding that helps make health care affordable for families, known as cost sharing reduction payments, was about claiming a political win, not supporting American families. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office said that if the administration stopped paying the cost sharing reduction payments, as it has now done, families’ premiums would jump by about 20 percent, many families would be left without health insurance options, and it would add $194 billion to the deficit over a decade. 47 percent of North Dakota consumers on the health insurance marketplace receive cost sharing reduction payments. We already saw Medica leave the North Dakota insurance market just based on the threat that these payments wouldn’t happen – now it’s a reality. Several months ago, I cosponsored a bill to fix this problem so the administration couldn’t take away North Dakotans’ health care with the stroke of a pen. And over the past several weeks, I’ve been working with a bipartisan group of senators on some immediate fixes to the health care system – and these payments are at the top of our list. We need real, bipartisan solutions to improve health care for families and make sure every child has access to the affordable health care they deserve. Anything less is just wrong.

Lindsay Vivier White was a member of the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians. She was a friendly and outgoing 28-year-old mother to three boys and three girls who was beloved by her community. Called ‘Linds’ by her family and many friends, Lindsay loved sugar cookies, her job as a waitress, and shared a deep love of the gospel with her mother-in-law – with whom she would exchange text messages of Bible verses. On July 20, 2017, her badly decomposed body was found near Williston, ND. Police ruled her death a homicide, but the prime suspect had killed himself not long after Lindsay’s murder.  Two men who are suspected of helping conceal Lindsay’s murder currently sit in jail. Lindsay’s family lives with too many unanswered questions and with the fear that the answers and justice may never come.

Cancer touches all of our lives – whether we’ve fought the battle ourselves, lost a loved one, or supported someone fighting for their life. If we work together, invest in medical research, continue to raise awareness, and promote detection methods, I’m hopeful that we can get rid of cancer in our lifetime.

Today I offered an amendment to the Senate budget bill – which will be voted on later today - that would prohibit taxes from being raised on middle income Americans. I’ve heard from teachers, nurses, veterans, small business owners, and working parents who are worried – they’re worried every day how to get by. This amendment would address those concerns by guaranteeing that those making under $250,000 don’t see their taxes go up in any legislation, including any tax reform proposal. This amendment would make sure Congress is focused on these workers, families, and retirees – not the wealthiest among us.

When farmers and ranchers walk in to an FSA office, they show up to get help – not an IOU. The drought has increased demand on our FSA offices, so we should be increasing the staff to adequately serve our farm communities. I greatly appreciate Secretary Perdue heeding my call for jump teams to be deployed over the summer, and today I urged him to again send supplemental staff to western North Dakota offices address the high volume of assistance applications due to the ongoing drought, especially during harvest. This is about getting our farmers and ranchers the assistance they need in a timely manner, so we must ensure that our FSA offices get immediate help and are also able to hire the full time staff necessary to serve our rural communities.

Disappointed that the U.S. Senate passed a budget resolution that would hurt North Dakotans. For generations, families and businesses across North Dakota have done better because of federal investments in programs that were designed to help our communities and local economies thrive. But instead of continuing those smart investments, this budget slashes educational programs from Pell Grants and Head Start, to those that help low-income families find safe, affordable housing and make sure seniors can heat their homes in the winter. What’s worse, it would absolutely gut health care for those who need it most – our seniors on Medicare and rural facilities that depend on Medicaid would see their access to quality care disintegrate – risking the long term health not just of our families and seniors, but the vitality of our rural towns. Simply, this bill hurts rural America and that's why I can't support it. I've long said I want to work on comprehensive, smart tax reforms that help rural economies, and voting against this budget doesn't change that. But for tax reform to work, Republicans and Democrats need to be at the table as it's drafted, and any proposal must support workers, families, and retirees.

The drought in North Dakota has hit our farmers and ranchers hard and it’s critical that we get the help in place that we promised to do. This is why I have pushed the U.S. Department of Agriculture to send more Farm Service Agency workers to understaffed areas of western North Dakota so that they receive the support they need now. Read more from this story in the Associated Press: http://bismarcktribune.com/news/state-and-regional/senator-calls-for-more-usda-workers-to-respond-to-drought/article_f6ae10b8-727c-5d64-82c9-c3c22d40ea9c.html?utm_content=buffere5bf6&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=LEEDCC

Today I had the chance to talk with experts and leaders at a panel hosted by University of North Dakota School of Law and the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children who have seen and understand child exploitation tragedies and how they have impacted children, our families, and our communities. When someone sexually violates a child they not only commit one of the most vile crimes imaginable but they steal their innocence and create lifelong trauma for their victims. Some online companies like Backpage.com knowingly help facilitate sex trafficking, especially of young children – and made money doing so. And sexual predators like traffickers and others are well aware that children in Indian Country are easier targets because of their remote locations and systems alerting communities when they go missing often don’t exist or are not synced with statewide or regional systems on tribal lands. During our discussion today, we talked about solutions to protect our kids and prevent these tragedies from happening. We can take action now not only to close legal loopholes to stop companies like Backpage.com from selling children online, or expand AMBER Alert systems on and outside of Native lands, but to also work together to form strong and comprehensive local and statewide responses. I’ll keep working for and with our community leaders, experts, and law enforcement to keep our children safe and get those who would do them harm off our streets and behind bars.

Read more in this Grand Forks Herald article about my discussion with national and local experts at UND last week on the need for community and policy solutions to help prevent trafficking and sexual exploitation and support missing children. This isn’t just a social worker’s problem, a cop’s problem, or a legislator’s problem – it’s all of our problem because these are all of our kids.

Today the U.S. Mint unveiled the design of the nation’s first-ever Commemorative Coin to raise funds for breast cancer research and awareness – which was made possible through my bipartisan legislation that was signed into law last year. As a survivor of breast cancer, I know how important it is that we raise awareness about this disease and I understand the impact breast cancer has on millions of women and families across this country. These coins are for the many courageous women fighting this disease, those who have overcome it, those we have lost, and the families and friends impacted. Working together on initiatives like this coin, we can make a real difference.

Children are the future of our state and country – and so it’s critically important that we give them the support they need to succeed and thrive. In North Dakota alone, more than 2,000 children rely on the Children’s Health Insurance Program – known as CHIP – to get routine check-ups, immunizations, dental care, and more.  It’s unacceptable that CHIP expired because it wasn’t reauthorized and we must act fast to change it. These children are counting on us to do what’s right. We must act fast to reauthorize this crucial program.

Read more in this The Bismarck Tribune article about why I joined three of my colleagues to share our #MeToo stories on Meet the Press last week. Ending sexual harassment or assault is about more than changing laws or punishing certain behavior – both are important – but it requires a comprehensive cultural change to instill the values that say as a society this is not ok and this is not acceptable. I hope more women now feel empowered to speak up and to defend their right to live free of harassment and assault.

ICYMI – yesterday I guest co-hosted CNBC’s Squawk Box and talked about how the main goal of any tax reform bill should be helping our state's small businesses owners, workers, families, and retirees who have worked harder than ever, but too often are still struggling. We need tax reform that levels the playing field for North Dakota workers, families, and small businesses, protects and secures retirements, makes it easier and less costly for families and businesses to file taxes, and is fiscally responsible. We have to get this right, which is why I held a listening tour with stops in Fargo, Grand Forks, Bismarck, and Minot to hear directly from folks about their priorities and concerns.

North Dakota’s farmers and ranchers feed our state, the country, and the world – and it’s critical that they get the support they need to continue to operate during good and bad times. That’s why today I introduced a bipartisan bill with Republican U.S. Senator Joni Ernst from Iowa that would strengthen and improve the Agriculture Risk Coverage-County Level program (ARC-CO) to better serve the farmers who need it most. As I’ve met with producers across our state over the past few months, they have made clear that improvements are necessary to programs like ARC-CO that help our agriculture community get through challenges like drought and low commodity prices. Two years ago, I successfully pressed USDA to make a fix so farmers who produce in more than one county get the payments they deserve – this bill builds on those efforts.

Today, the U.S. Senate Committee on Indian Affairs will hold a hearing on Savanna’s Act, my bill to help combat the epidemic of missing and murdered Native women. Please watch the hearing live at the website below at 1:30pmCT/2:30pmET. Native women face violence, exploitation, and murder at astonishing and unacceptable rates – 84% of Native women experience violence in their lifetime. And on some reservations, Native women are murdered at 10 times the national average. At this hearing, Carmen O’Leary of the Native Women’s Society of the Great Plains will testify on the urgent need for my bill to help protect women and girls from violence, abduction, and human trafficking this legislation.

Important WDAZ-TV story about the need for my bipartisan bill with Republican U.S. Senator John McCain from Arizona that would help boost protections for Native American children by expanding child abduction warnings, known as Amber Alerts in Indian Country. When such alerts do exist in Indian Country, they’re often limited to tribal lands and don’t reach the public and law enforcement beyond the reservation – a vulnerability criminals can too easily exploit. Building on this bill, I also introduced Savanna’s Act earlier this month that would help combat the crisis of missing and murdered Native American women. Both of these bills aim to help stop the exploitation, violence, and trafficking of Native women and children.

Excited to meet Carson Wentz’s dad and family in my Washington, DC office today. Carson represents North Dakota so well in not just his athleticism, but with his work ethic and empathy. After meeting his family today, it’s easy to see where he gets it from.
Working for North Dakota in the U.S. Senate

Today the U.S. Senate Committee on Indian Affairs held a hearing on my bipartisan bill to help address the epidemic of missing and murdered Native American women, Savanna’s Act. To better protect Native women, we must start by raising awareness about the epidemic of missing and murdered Native women to bring this terrible problem out of the shadows, and then find solutions. Savanna LaFontaine-Greywind and so many other Native women whose lives were taken too soon – or have gone missing – must never be forgotten, and with this bill and today’s hearing we’re working to make sure that moving forward we are doing more to prevent these tragic crimes from continuing to wreak havoc on the  lives of Native women and their families. https://goo.gl/qud9cU

Without the bipartisan health care bill led by U.S. Senators Lamar Alexander (R-TN) and Patty Murray (D-WA) that I helped work on, families will lose access to health coverage, premiums will go up, and the deficit will balloon because the administration is taking action that hurts families’ health care. We can’t let that happen. This bill was crafted through a thoughtful, deliberative process that included input from many Republicans and Democrats – that’s how bills should be crafted and I was proud to be part of the effort. But our bill can only help families if it receives a vote and passes. I hope more members of Congress speak up and call for a vote on this bill, and I hope families have their voices heard to help get this bill passed. After we address some of the immediate health care needs, then we can work on other bills to make longer-term fixes to the health care system so it works better for North Dakota families, as I’ve long been pushing for.

The tragedies Native American women face persist daily in America, yet they do not command the spotlight or attention they deserve. Read my op-ed in the Grand Forks Herald about my bipartisan bill, Savanna’s Act, that aims to raise awareness about the epidemic of missing and murdered Native American women and improve law enforcement coordination to combat these crimes. Just yesterday, the U.S. Senate Committee on Indian Affairs held a hearing on Savanna’s Act – an important step to getting this legislation passed in Congress and signed into law.

The brave men and women who put on the uniform and risk their lives and serve our country deserve our thanks each and every day. That’s why I’m proud to have helped pass a bipartisan resolution declaring today ‘Day of the Deployed’ to pay tribute to the nation’s deployed service members and their families. To truly honor their service, it also means making sure our servicemembers and veterans are able to get the health care and support they earned, and I’ll keep working to make sure that happens. I encourage Americans to take a step back and pay tribute not just to our deployed servicemembers, but also to their families and loved ones at home.

Just three weeks after it was introduced, my bill to help combat the epidemic of missing and murdered Native American women – called Savanna’s Act, had a hearing in the U.S. Senate Committee on Indian Affairs. Read this The Bismarck Tribune article for more on how the hearing on Savanna’s Act reinforced this crisis in Indian Country and highlighted how my bipartisan bill would help address it.

Great to have Rep. Joshua A. Boschee, a great friend and great legislator from Fargo, testify at my U.S. Senate subcommittee hearing on the states’ regulatory process. Josh doesn’t just talk about making things better for North Dakotans, he rolls up his sleeves and gets to work. This hearing was an opportunity for the subcommittee to learn about how states have tackled many questions we’re considering around regulations and I’m grateful that Josh could make the trip to talk about what folks are doing back in North Dakota. Joined Republican U.S. Senator Joni Ernst from Iowa to introduce our bipartisan bill that would give small businesses a bigger seat at the table and a stronger voice if a proposed regulation could hurt their ability to grow. Small businesses are the backbone of North Dakota’s economy, and we need to make sure they have a level playing field to grow, thrive, and create jobs. This bill would make sure that the needs of small businesses have to be considered as regulations are created so we can prevent red tape and burdensome rules from unfairly impacting them.

The president declaring opioid abuse a public health emergency today is a good step to help raise awareness about the epidemic of opioid abuse, which has taken far too many lives and impacted far too many families across North Dakota and the country. What communities need right now is more resources, and it’s up to the federal government to help provide that support. Last year, Congress passed important legislation to help address this epidemic, and I’m still pushing to pass a bill I helped introduce that would help fill in some of the gaps by actually providing federal resources that our communities and states need to help tackle this crisis. The federal government must continue to raise awareness about this issue, but it also needs to provide the teeth to put that awareness into results that can save lives. And that includes defending Medicaid, which covers one-third of adults with opioid addiction.

The crisis of missing and murdered Native American women isn’t new – it’s been happening for decades. This High Plains Reader article outlines the challenges families face when a loved one goes missing and the agony of never getting justice or closure. It also shares more heartbreaking stories about women who were taken too soon. This is unacceptable. My bipartisan bill, Savanna’s Act, aims to help combat this epidemic – but we need your help too. We have to raise awareness about this so talk about it, share the stories, and help make sure these stories are heard.

84% of Native American women experience violence in their lifetimes, and on some reservations, Native women are murdered at 10 times the national average. This has to stop. We need to raise awareness about the epidemic of missing and murdered Native women to bring this terrible problem out of the shadows, and then find solutions – and that’s what Savanna’s Act aims to do. Last week, my bipartisan bill was discussed in the U.S. Senate Committee, an important first step to combating this heartbreaking crisis.

Congress is failing the nine million kids nationwide - including more than 2,000 North Dakotans - who rely on the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) by failing to reauthorize this critical program. CHIP enables children to have routine check-ups, immunizations, check-ups, and many other important health services. CHIP expired exactly a month ago today – it’s past time that the federal government take action and reauthorize this program.

Four years ago today I introduced my first bill as a U.S. senator – bipartisan legislation to create a Commission on Native Children and protect Native American youth. So proud that this important bill was signed into law last year, bringing us one step closer to living up to our trust and treat responsibilities. Native youth often have the cards stacked against them from the beginning – facing higher rates of suicide and poverty, and low graduation rates. Through the Commission, this law will help address the complex challenges Native youth face and give them hope for a better future.

Encourage folks to get out and support their local military-owned businesses this week for National Veterans Small Business Week. All week the U.S. Small Business Administration will focus on celebrating, connecting, and empowering veterans, servicemembers, and military family entrepreneurs and small business owners by sharing stories of successful veteran entrepreneurs. The brave men and women who put on the uniform and serve our country often keep serving when they get home, and this week is an opportunity to highlight the wonderful work they continue to do in our communities.

Today at a U.S. Senate Committee hearing, I spoke with the FEMA Administrator and other top officials in charge of coordinating a federal response to hurricanes about how they think the government has responded so far, and what more we need to do. I also reinforced that one of my main concerns is that talking about mitigation and preparedness will take a back seat as folks deal with the disasters in Puerto Rico and other places hard hit this hurricane season. Federal agencies should be able to respond appropriately to current disasters while also better preparing how to handle future ones. Recent news reports indicate that House Republicans may drastically limit pre-tax contribution limits to 401K retirement savings accounts in tax reform, lowering the cap from $18,000 to $2,400. Taking that step would raise taxes on North Dakota families and reduce their retirement savings. Men and women in rural America are working hard and playing by the rules, but it's getting more and more difficult for them to make an honest living while saving for retirement. That’s just wrong, and we can’t allow actions that will take away families’ safety net. I’ve long said I'm eager to work with Republicans and Democrats on a tax reform package that simplifies the tax system and reduces taxes on hard-pressed middle income families and small businesses, but limiting folks’ ability to save for retirement is not the answer.

Open enrollment for health care begins today and ends December 15. Read this InForum article about how this year, the administration shortened the enrollment period by a month and a half, and stripping funding for many organizations to help folks enroll and learn their options. I’ve always said that the current health care law isn’t perfect, but we must find a solution that keeps costs affordable for families and make care accessible, and that’s what the bipartisan deal I helped work on in the U.S. Senate would do – and Congress needs to vote on it.

Helped pass a bipartisan resolution to recognize November as Native American Heritage Month to honor the culture and history of our first people. Native Americans have influenced our country for centuries – impacting the founding of our nation, serving in the military and as code talkers in World War II, and helping maintain vibrant and rich traditions that remind us of the past as we also look to the future for Native communities. It’s because of that history that the federal government must uphold its trust and treaty responsibilities to tribes, and we must make sure they are not forgotten. The federal government must do better to support Native families and communities, and this resolution is a reminder of that.

North Dakota has a proud tradition of manufacturers and small business owners, and for generations, they’ve been able to compete on a global scale with the help of loan guarantees of the Export-Import Bank. But over the past several years, some members of Congress have stalled the bank from operating or fully functioning for political reasons and hurt American workers and businesses. Today at a U.S. Senate Committee hearing, I asked the president’s nominee to lead the bank, Scott Garrett, for an apology to the American small businesses and workers he hurt by his staunch, political opposition to the Export-Import Bank. But he refused the chance to reconcile his past, or to prove he wouldn’t act as a saboteur of the Bank. The Ex-Im Bank doesn’t cost taxpayers a dime, has supported thousands of U.S. jobs including many across North Dakota, and helps boost rural economies – supporting it should be a no-brainer. It’s interesting that now that Garrett wants a job, he’s suddenly had a change of tune. Unfortunately for him, I don’t buy it and neither do the American workers he left stranded when he was in Congress. https://goo.gl/t9N1F4

Our bipartisan deal is an important step, and just as I’ve done over the past several years, I’ll keep offering proposals to help it work better for North Dakotans.

Read this Agweek article about how my bipartisan bill with Republican U.S. Senator Joni Ernst would address challenges farmers have faced with ARC-CO payments for years. Helped lead a U.S. Senate Committee hearing focused on the many challenges the 2020 Census faces. The data gathered through the Census informs the levels of federal funding that North Dakota and other states receive for transportation infrastructure, education, medical assistance, and many other essential programs. My main concerns is the lack of trust in the ability of the federal government to keep personal information safe and I want to know what the U.S. Census Bureau is doing to build that trust and public confidence in its work. I also urged the Census Bureau to do a better job assessing the needs in rural and tribal communities for housing, job training, social services, and much more. Led bipartisan group of Members of Congress to submit an amicus brief to the U.S. Supreme Court urging it to reconsider and overturn a 25 year-old case determining whether states can require out-of-state businesses like online vendors to collect and remit state sales and use taxes. Not requiring out-of-state retailers and online vendors to collect sales and use taxes has disadvantaged small businesses and their workers for too long. The Supreme Court should re-visit and reverse the previous decision that tipped the scales in favor of online retailers and against brick and mortar businesses around the country which support our local towns, and which lose close to $26 billion every year because of a misguided decision over two decades ago. It’s past time to level the playing field for local shops across our communities.

The latest episode of my podcast, ‘The Hotdish,’ is up and it focuses on the epidemic of missing and murdered Native women. Talked with two experts and advocates, Lisa Brunner and Sadie Young Bird, about their work helping indigenous women overcome obstacles and hardship. Every day I come to work in the U.S. Senate, I think about women and girls like Savanna LaFontaine-Greywind, who were so needlessly and tragically lost. One idea I’ve put forward is a bill called Savanna’s Act, which aims to help tackle these challenges and improve cooperation among law enforcement agencies at all levels. We must raise awareness about this horrible epidemic to create change and fight for justice and to keep our Native communities – and every community – strong and safe. Please listen to this episode, help spread the word and raise awareness about this crisis, and help us make changes. Joined folks in Bismarck today to welcome home Miss America & celebrate Cara Mund day! So proud of how well Cara represents North Dakota across the country and her work to give back to and help those in need.

Secured a commitment from U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer that he will protect agriculture in any NAFTA renegotiations. During our discussion on the need to protect agriculture, I pressed Lighthizer about how pulling out of NAFTA altogether would be devastating to farm jobs in the United States and he pledged to continue his engagement with me and other advocates for a robust agriculture exports policy as NAFTA discussions continue. North Dakota farmers export their top notch products around the world, and Mexico and Canada are often some of the top importers, and we can’t close that market for them.

To celebrate November being National Adoption Month, I’m highlighting North Dakotans who I’ve had the honor of nominating to be Angels in Adoption over the last four years. In 2013, that family was Courtney and Bobby Williams from Dickinson who, in addition to three biological children, became trained foster caregivers and adopted three children - a girl from the Democratic Republic of Congo and two boys from Ethiopia. Courtney and Bobby understand the positive and life changing effects their actions have on the children they bring into their home and they deserve to be recognized for what they do today and every day.

Children are the future of our state and we have a responsibility to make sure they grow up healthy and happy. That’s why it’s absolutely urgent that Congress works to extend the Children’s Health Insurance Program, known as CHIP. CHIP – a program that’s been used since the late 1990s and more than 2,000 North Dakota children rely on for affordable health care -- expired 38 days ago. We must act fast to reauthorize CHIP and let the thousands of children across the country who are on CHIP know that we care about them.

Olivia Lone Bear from New Town has been missing since October 24. Grateful to hear about the folks coming together to search for her over the weekend. Read more about what’s being done and how you can help.

North Korea’s nuclear weapons and missile programs threaten the safety of American families, as well as our allies and interests in the region. Congress must take action to counter the threat – that’s why today in the U.S. Senate Banking Committee, I voted for secondary sanctions that are another important way to cut off the financial support that has allowed North Korea to advance its dangerous and illegal programs. This bill also included my amendment that would help us better understand how North Korea benefits from bad actor nations like Iran which help North Korea commit financial crimes and enable its illegal pursuit of nuclear weapon and ballistic missile technology. This information would help the U.S. with a tough, smart national security strategy to keep American families safe.

Congratulations to Sanford Health Clinics in Bismarck for being named a Million Hearts 2017 Hypertension Control Champion. Over the past year, Sanford Health Clinics used a variety of approaches and strategies to get more than 70% of its patients to control their high blood pressure. The facilities in Bismarck are one of 24 Champions nationwide that are being recognized for their work to prevent heart attacks and strokes by promoting and implementing blood pressure control. In North Dakota, nearly 29% of adults have high blood pressure, and it’s dedicated health care professionals like these folks that help make our communities and families healthier.

On behalf of the North Dakota Association of Rural Electric Cooperatives, I pushed USDA for transparency in its grant making process. Since 1994, NDAREC has used a USDA grant to support its successful cooperative development center. However, this year, its application received a drastically reduced score which led NDAREC to ask for basic information of the grant to be disclosed. Information on who received grants or loans, the amount, and intended use of federal funds is reasonable information that a federal agency should disclose – so when USDA denied NDAREC’s request, they reached out to me.

Today at a U.S. Senate Committee hearing, I secured a commitment from the nominee to lead the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, Kirstjen Nielsen, to visit North Dakota and prioritize addressing challenges at the Northern Border. Both in my meeting with Nielsen last month, and in the hearing today, I was encouraged to hear that she shares the view that implementing a new Northern Border strategy – a DHS initiative which came as a result of my bill becoming law – must be done as quickly as possible. If Neilsen is confirmed, I will hold her accountable for the commitments she made today so that we can keep our communities and nation strong and safe. https://goo.gl/Nf5p3x

The U.S. Senate Committee on Commerce passed a bipartisan bill I helped write and introduce that would hold websites like Backpage accountable for their role in knowingly facilitating sex trafficking online. This bill would stop websites from providing a platform for – and profiting from – this modern form of slavery by making sure victims of this hideous form of exploitation can seek justice. A Congressional investigation into Backpage found evidence for its role to facilitate the sale of young children for sex online – and it truly made me sick to watch leaders of the site hide behind their First Amendment rights when we held a hearing on it earlier this year. We are now one step closer to bringing justice to children who were sold for sex online and their families.

It was an honor to meet Rhonda McCowan Grimmer and her family in Washington today. The family is in town for the reading of names – including their family member, Private First Class Ralph C. McCowan – on the Vietnam Veterans Memorial wall to mark its 35th anniversary. Ralph was one of the 160 North Dakotans who never came home from the Vietnam War who I honored on the floor of the U.S. Senate in 2015. It’s absolutely wonderful that the family can come out here to see where Ralph is being remembered and thanked for his service and sacrifice. Meeting Rhonda and her family was a wonderful way to head into Veterans Day weekend.

On the floor of the U.S. Senate, I pushed for adequate support from trained professionals to help North Dakotans sign up for health coverage during open enrollment and urged Congress to vote on the bipartisan deal I worked on that would address immediate challenges in our health care system. I also called for action to reauthorize the Children Health Insurance Program – known as CHIP – which expired more than a month ago and 9 million children nationwide rely on for health care.

It’s days like today, Veterans Day, when I’m particularly grateful for the many opportunities I’ve had to honor North Dakota veterans and servicemembers. One of the most meaningful projects I’ve worked on in the U.S. Senate was partnering with Bismarck High School in 2015 to commemorate the 50th Anniversary of the Vietnam War by honoring North Dakotans who made the ultimate sacrifice. We did this in many ways – I shared stories about the lives of those we lost on the floor of the U.S. Senate and created an interactive webpage to remember them (https://goo.gl/TTBYTJ). The students did projects on fallen sliders and created artifacts in their honor that they brought to Washington, DC to lay at the Vietnam War Memorial. Working with the students and teachers at Bismarck High School was a true privilege, and meeting the families of those who lost loved ones so long ago was an incredible experience. It also serves as a reminder that we can and must do more to honor those who fought for our freedom – and that includes making sure they have the health care and support they need when they come home.

Open enrollment to sign up for or change your health care coverage is now until December 15. Check out my webpage that has information and resources to help North Dakotans find out their options and determine the best plan for their families.

Great to join folks in Bismarck today for the AMVETS Veterans Day program to honor North Dakota servicemembers and veterans for their sacrifice and commitment to our nation. Honored the men and women who selflessly served our country at the VFW’s All-Veteran Centennial Memorial in Bismarck today. For National Adoption Month, I want to once again honor Ina Olson from Belcourt. On Agri-Pulse Communications, Inc.'s Open Mic, I talked about how the drought and low commodity prices impacted North Dakota producers this year and my work to strengthen and maintain provisions folks across the state rely on in the 2018 Farm Bill.

Important op-ed in the Washington Post about the lack of access to maternity services in rural areas. 85% of the North Dakota’s rural counties lack obstetric services, meaning that expecting mothers often have to travel outside the county and long distances for care during their pregnancy and when they go into labor. Unlike any other industrialized country, maternal deaths in the United States raised by an alarming 26% from 2000 to 2014 alone. That’s unacceptable – and my bipartisan bill with Republican U.S. Senator Shelly Moore Capito from West Virginia would work to address this by expanding resources to study why pregnancy related deaths are happening. Everyone – no matter where you live – should have access to the resources they need to have healthy pregnancies and healthy babies.

30 years ago, there were more than 14,000 banks in the United States. But today, there are approximately 5,000. In North Dakota, more than 80% of deposits still go to community banks – reinforcing that they are a lifeline in rural communities. After 3 years of negotiations, I’m proud to have helped negotiate and write a bipartisan bill that would provide regulatory relief for community banks and credit unions, protect and support consumers, and boost economic growth. Particularly in these partisan times, this bill is an example of how Congress can work together to reach real, tangible results through compromise and good faith negotiations. Click below to read more about our bipartisan bill.

Every day I come to work in the U.S. Senate, I’m fighting for rural America. That’s why after hearing directly from community banks and credit unions about how burdensome regulations are holding them back, I got to work. For 3 years, I’ve been working with a bipartisan group of senators to reach a compromise deal on legislation that would provide regulatory relief for community banks and credit unions, protect and support consumers, and boost economic growth. This deal is an example of how if Democrats and Republicans put partisanship aside and work together, we can reach real compromises that provide real, tangible results in North Dakota and across the country. And it’s an example of how I try to work and get results every day for our state in the U.S. Senate.

I know so many families across North Dakota who, without the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), would be bankrupt today trying to come out from under a mountain of debt caused by unexpected medical costs for their children. CHIP makes sure this doesn’t happen by making sure children have access to affordable and quality routine checkups, immunizations, dental care, and more. The 9 million children nationwide – including 2,000 in North Dakota – who use this program and their families are counting on Congress to do its job and reauthorize this critical program. Congress needs to act now to make sure these families know that their children will continue to have dependable and secure health care.

After a 10 month deployment, 60 North Dakota National Guard servicemembers are coming home this week. Words can't describe how grateful I am for their service and sacrifice - and everything their families gave up for our nation. Not only did these brave servicemembers put their lives on the line, they missed birthdays, soccer games, and so much more to do it. Thank you to all those who served and for the folks coming home this week – know that we appreciate your sacrifice.

Every young person deserves the chance to reach their full potential, but it’s heartbreaking that so many children and young adults lack a stable home to keep them safe and support their growth and development. A new study found that 1 in 10 young adults experience homelessness over 1 year, and at least 1 in 30 adolescents between 13 – 17 years old. These staggering statistics reinforce the need for the bipartisan Runaway and Homeless Youth Act – a bipartisan bill that would provide critical community-based care, housing, and counseling to homeless youth and young adults.

Where you live shouldn’t determine what kind of health care you have access too. In North Dakota, most folks live in a rural area meaning that rural health care is critical for families and communities all across our state. Today for National Rural Health Day, I want to thank the hard working and dedicated doctors, nurses, lab technicians, and other health care professionals that continue to provide top-notch care for rural patients close to home.

Voted with a bipartisan majority of the U.S. Senate to pass a defense spending bill that includes many wins for North Dakota’s military installations which support our national security and boost our economy. In 2015, I carefully and successfully crafted a bipartisan deal to lift the 40-year old ban on exporting oil while also providing long-term certainty for renewable energies. Included in that deal was an extension of the Production Tax Credit which I had long pushed for to support the development of wind energy – tax credits that have helped create a wind boom in North Dakota and across the mid-west. Just this week, three wind energy projects were approved by the North Dakota Public Service Commission – creating more good-paying jobs, diversifying our energy mix, and supporting local economies. We’ve seen firsthand how instrumental the Production Tax Credit has been for wind energy development in North Dakota. I’ll fight for a smart tax reform bill that levels the playing field, is fiscally responsible, and also gives businesses and industries the certainty they need to grow and thrive.

Led a bipartisan effort to warn of the potential impacts of renegotiating or withdrawing from NAFTA, and to protect North Dakota dry pea producers form India’s unfair trade practices. Join me today to help raise awareness about the crisis of missing and murdered Native American women by sharing a photo holding a #NotInvisible sign on Facebook and Twitter. 84% of Native American women experience some kind of violence in their lifetime, and on some reservations, they are murdered at 10 times the national average. This is unacceptable. Help raise awareness about this epidemic and bring this issue out of the shadows so it is no longer invisible -- then can we then help implement solutions to stop these tragedies from occurring. Please, spread the word, join me to show your support, and together we can make sure Native American women get the protection that they deserve.

November is Native American Heritage Month and it’s a reminder to reflect on the history and traditions of Native Americans, and it’s also a reminder that our indigenous populations face many challenges that urgently require awareness and solutions. To make a real, lasting change, I need your help – so please spread the word, show your support, and help bring to light these terrible crimes. Folks in Indian Country across our nation know all too well about the epidemic of missing and murdered Native women as so many of the are directly impacted by it every day. But outside those communities and reservations, the issue lacks the awareness it deserves. By sharing photos holding a sign that says #NotInvisible, we’re standing with Native women, their families, advocates, and supporters to bring this crisis out of the shadows and say that Native women are not invisible. Only once we raise awareness about this epidemic can we then help implement solutions to stop these tragedies from occurring.

The folks at TAT Victim Services went above and beyond today to help raise awareness about the crisis of missing and murdered Native American women. I’ve had the chance to work with TAT Victim Services Director Sadie Young Bird and hear firsthand about the incredible work her and her team do in New Town to empower individuals who are abused, victimized, in economic distress, and in need of resources or emotional support. It’s organizations like this that have a life-changing impacts on the people they serves. Greatly appreciate these folks lending their voice today, and am especially grateful for all of their hard work day in and day out to support Native American women and the tribal community. #NotInvisible

Stella, Monica, Lakota, Mona Lisa, and Lindsay are just a few of the countless stories of Native American women who have gone missing or been murdered with no closure or justice to follow. This is an epidemic in Indian Country – 84% of Native American women experience violence in their lifetime. And on some reservations, Native women are murdered at 10 times the national average. We have to raise awareness about this issue so we can find solutions to combat – and I need your help to do that. Today, I’m asking folks to take a photo with a #NotInvisible sign and post it on Facebook and Twitter so we can let folks know that these crimes and these women can no longer be invisible. Please share these stories, show your support, and let’s put an end to this unacceptable level of violence.
