As North Dakota’s former tax commissioner, I’ve been eager to work with Republicans and Democrats on tax reform to give hard working men and women a needed tax break. Tax issues are important and complicated, and that’s why Congress needed to work together, Republicans and Democrats, on tax reform. After holding listening sessions across North Dakota, having many discussions about tax reform with top White House officials including the president, and trying to change this bill so it supports working families, it’s discouraging that Senate Republicans weren’t willing to work with us on it. Instead, this bill was crafted at the last minute behind closed doors. And it shows – this bill is bad for North Dakota.  With this legislation, Congress is handing our children a credit card bill with nearly $1.5 trillion of debt – and that’s in the best-case scenario. We need to have an honest conversation about what that means for us long-term. Now, we won’t be able to spend that money on finding a cure for Alzheimer’s and cancer, addressing the opioid epidemic, fixing the country’s pension crisis, boosting national security, rebuilding degraded infrastructure, supporting agriculture research, or providing disaster assistance. All that money will have been spent on tax reform.  Additionally, this bill tries to buy off middle income families for almost nothing, while the wealthy get richer at their expense. In North Dakota, the top one percent – those making over $604,800 – will see an average tax cut of $46,870. The president and most members of Congress will benefit from this bill. Meanwhile, North Dakotans making under $75,220 – 60 percent of those in our state -- will get an average tax cut of just a few hundred dollars. Look at that disparity – there’s nothing fair about it. On the other hand, if these tax cuts were given out evenly across the board rather than disproportionately to the wealthy, every American would get a $9,000 tax cut, but that isn’t what is happening.  I wanted to be able to support a responsible, permanent tax reform bill that stands up for workers, families, and retirees while staying fiscally responsible. I wanted to help write it. But this bill gives large corporations a permanent tax cut, while the tax cuts for working families expire in a few years. It could hurt North Dakota seniors by cutting $400 billion from Medicare. It puts farm programs and the Farm Bill at risk. It makes it more difficult for young families to buy homes. It will be harder for students to afford a college education. It makes it more complicated for small businesses to file taxes. It will take health care away from 13 million families. Teachers won’t be able to buy the school supplies they need. Nonprofit organizations will receive fewer donations to operate and help struggling families. The bill could force cuts for federal oil, gas, and coal payments to North Dakota by $40 million per year. And all the top academics – Republicans and Democrats – say it won’t grow the economy or create jobs in the way Republicans say it will.  It’s up to Congress to set a responsible path forward for our country. This bill is bad business and it’s about a political win, but the detrimental impacts of it will be felt across North Dakota and the country. Every day when I come to work in the U.S. Senate, I’m fighting for families across rural America – the workers, parents, retirees, and children -- who are counting on us to stand up for them and do the right thing for them. But under this bill, they will lose, and that’s why I can’t vote for it.

North Dakota’s drought has hit farmers, ranchers, & honey bee producers hard. As I’ve traveled across the state to hear firsthand about the impact of the drought, it’s clear that Congress can improve the way disaster assistance is provided in difficult times like these. That’s why I’ve put forward some common sense reforms to make sure our disaster relief programs work when they’re needed the most.

Last month I testified at a hearing on unfairly subsidized biodiesel imports from Argentina and Indonesia that are harming North Dakota. I’m glad the U.S. International Trade Commission listened to my concerns and those expressed by our farmers and biodiesel producers, and decided to level the playing field by imposing duties on imports of unfairly subsidized product. This is a win for North Dakota jobs and home-grown energy.

Started the #NotInvisible campaign to bring attention to the epidemic of murdered and missing Native American women. And my bill, Savanna's Act, is a needed step to help address this crisis. Join me in urging action to stand up for Native women.

Finding a bipartisan plan to fully fund health insurance for children should be common sense. Over 2,000+ North Dakota children rely on CHIP for health coverage they need to stay healthy. The New York Times details how Congress’s inability to work together is causing more problems for our nation’s children – this must change for the sake of our kids.

Volunteer first responders sacrifice a lot to protect our communities, and fire departments face many challenges recruiting new volunteers. Today I helped introduce a bill that would provide federal student loan forgiveness to eligible volunteer first responders, so that more men and women in rural America are encouraged to serve their communities as firefighters and EMS personnel. By making it easier for departments to recruit and retain volunteers, we can help our first responders focus on keeping our communities strong and safe.

Women have been courageously stepping out of the shadows to tell their stories of sexual harassment and abuse, which oftentimes occurs in the workplace. We need to empower all victims to come forward and speak out, to prevent harassment and abuse, and to impose serious consequences when they do happen. That’s why I’ve joined Senators Kirsten Gillibrand, Lindsay Graham, and others in a bipartisan effort to end what’s known as forced arbitration, a process that sweeps systemic issues of abuse under the rug and denies victims the justice they deserve. Gretchen Carlson said it best: Enough is enough. We must end this unfair practice and give all workers full access to justice in the face of sexual harassment and abuse.

In rural America, you can buy a $90,000 pickup truck with a piece of paper, but you can’t buy a $40,000 house because mortgage regulations designed for big banks are harming small community lenders. This makes no sense, and it’s just one example of how one-size-fits-all regulation hurts rural states like North Dakota. After years of negotiations with Republicans and Democrats, I was proud to put forward a plan to give small lenders relief from burdensome regulations so they can help families, farmers, and small businesses in rural communities thrive.

96 percent of North Dakota’s firefighting forces are volunteer, which means they sacrifice their time and put their lives on the line for our communities with no expectation of compensation. Read this Williston Herald piece to learn more about how we’re trying to make it easier for volunteer first responders to serve.

I’ve put together some resources to help folks explore their options and choose the best plan. There isn’t time to waste –  protecting your health is too important.

The Senate Republican tax reform bill will put our kids on the hook to pay for its exorbitant cost without substantially growing the economy. We need to have an honest conversation about what American families are getting for that $1.5 trillion -- which the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office concluded the bill will cost. That’s a really big bill to put on our kids’ shoulders. And it will have a huge impact on their futures. With this same amount of money, the Senate could give every taxpayer making less than $200,000 per year a $9,000 tax cut, rather than disproportionately helping the wealthy as this bill does. Or the Senate could invest that money in priorities such as finding a cure for Alzheimer’s and cancer, rebuilding our country’s degraded infrastructure, expanding opioid abuse prevention and treatment programs, or fixing the country’s pension crisis. All of these priorities will be crowded out by the Senate’s deficit financed tax bill.

As I’ve talked to farmers and ranchers across North Dakota, it’s clear that Congress can improve programs that help our agriculture industry cope in times of drought and other hardship. That’s why I’ve put forward some common sense reforms to make sure our disaster relief programs work when they’re needed the most. Read more about my bill in the Bowman County Pioneer.

Olivia Lone Bear has been missing since October 24. Her family’s resolve to find her is inspiring, and law enforcement must work around the clock until she’s found. Tragically, Native American women go missing far more often than the national average. We must keep the spotlight on efforts to find Olivia and urgently work to address the crisis of missing and murdered indigenous women.

Strong net neutrality rules protect consumers – especially in rural areas – and I’m very concerned about the Federal Communication Commission’s plan to repeal protections that ensure basic fairness on the internet. I've expressed my strong concerns about the plan to FCC Commissioner Ajit Pai, because North Dakotans and small businesses lose out if their internet provider is allowed to infringe upon these basic principles. I’ve heard from many North Dakota startup companies worried that repeal of net neutrality could lead them to pay higher costs to do business on the internet, and I share their concerns. Repealing net neutrality could leave North Dakota’s rural communities more vulnerable, and the FCC needs to fully explain the impact of these changes.

The U.S. Capitol Police officers provide a critical service – they help make sure the U.S. Capitol is safe for members of Congress, staffers, and the public who come here every day to the U.S. Capitol Building. Today, several of my Senate colleagues and I delivered some Christmas cookies just to say thank you. On just one day in 2016, 80% of unmet requests for emergency domestic violence services in North Dakota were related to housing. By diverting funding away from transitional housing in recent years, the federal government has been inadvertently forcing communities to shutter emergency housing facilities, sometimes leaving victims and their families without a safe alternative. Today I helped introduce a bipartisan bill that would help level the playing field for transitional housing and encourage HUD to prioritize living options that work best for survivors — so that women and children have the residential stability to permanently escape their abusers.

The decision by the FCC today to roll back net neutrality protections is extremely disappointing. Having high-speed internet is no longer a luxury, today it’s a necessity. Each of us uses the internet daily to pay our bills, take online classes, and make routine purchases. Having strong net neutrality protections would have kept the internet on a level playing field to help allow start-up businesses to compete with large corporations and rural communities to access affordable internet service. It’s an issue of fairness. The FCC’s actions will ultimately undermine these safeguards. Going forward, I’ll monitor how internet service providers alter the way the internet is offered and work to find realistic solutions so that the internet can continue to thrive as an open and free platform for everyone.

I pushed the U.S. Geological Survey to fast-track a new study of available resources in the Bakken region, and it’s great news for North Dakota’s economy that it agreed to an expedited survey. Recent advances in resource recovery techniques mean the potential for more investment and more jobs in the region. Responsible energy extraction in the Bakken is essential to an all-of-the-above energy strategy, and this new study will help North Dakota remain an energy leader.

Unfortunately, Congress let the Children’s Health Insurance Program expire. Now is the time to work together to make sure this critical program gets reauthorized immediately. CHIP makes it possible for kids from lower-income families to receive the medical care they need to grow up strong and healthy.

Great evening at North Dakota Farmers Union 91st Annual Convention. I heard from many farmers concerned about how changes to the tax code and trade policy could affect them, and discussed my efforts to take the lessons we’re learning from the drought to make the 2018 Farm Bill work for all North Dakota farmers and ranchers.

Two years ago, I worked with Republican Senator Lisa Murkowski from Alaska to successfully help craft and negotiate a bipartisan deal to lift the 40-year old ban on exporting American crude oil. And for more than a year and a half leading up to that point, we had worked to build bipartisan support to end the ban. As a result, we were able to successfully encourage both parties to put politics aside, garner bipartisan support for lifting the ban, and gain enough momentum to reach a bipartisan deal to end this nonsensical policy.   The legislation paired lifting the outdated ban with support for renewable energies, including extending a critical tax credit for North Dakota’s wind producers. After years of listening to folks from all sides of the issue, the deal was a major victory for U.S. consumers and businesses, and it brought together Republicans and Democrats to advance America’s economy, national security, and energy security. This deal was an example of how I fight every day for the people of North Dakota in the U.S. Senate, and it shows how Congress can produce results, if it puts partisanship aside and really wants to work to find solutions for the American people.

As North Dakota’s former tax commissioner, I know taxes are complicated, and I’ve wanted to work on a bill that cuts taxes for working men and women who need a break. In fact, I’ve been almost begging Republicans to work with me on a bipartisan bill that could serve North Dakota. I held meetings in North Dakota on tax reform, and met with top White House officials, including the president, on the issue. Unfortunately, I never got a seat at the table, nor did many others. As a result, it produced a partisan tax bill that hurts North Dakota and is full of broken promises to the American people.    We were promised middle income tax cuts without cuts for the wealthy. But this bill gives huge, permanent tax cuts to corporations and millionaires while middle income families will see relatively modest cuts in the short-term and their costs go up in the long run.   We were promised a fiscally responsible bill. But this bill charges nearly $1.5 trillion on a credit card account to our children and grandchildren without a plan to pay for it.   We were promised a simpler tax code so we could file taxes on a postcard. But this bill makes the tax code even more confusing and more difficult for families to understand their tax liability.   We were promised no loopholes. But this bill is full of loopholes for real estate moguls, private jet companies, and others, enabling large corporations and the wealthy to pay lower taxes.   And we were promised a bill that would grow the economy. But experts and academics agree this bill won’t boost the economy the way Republicans say it will, and many executives have said they will use corporate tax cuts to pad their shareholders’ profits, not create jobs or boost wages.   Congress can’t build a successful bill if it is quickly crafted behind closed doors without input from both parties. I know that because I’ve crafted many bipartisan bills that serve North Dakota including lifting the ban on exporting oil, finding a viable path forward for coal, and giving community banks and credit unions relief. Those bills didn’t happen overnight – they took good faith negotiations, compromises from all sides, and a mutual effort to work across the aisle. That didn’t happen with this tax bill. And it shows. Every day, I come to work in the U.S. Senate to fight for North Dakota and rural America. Sadly, this bill leaves them behind.

51.5% of U.S. domestic violence victims who sought transitional housing did not receive it, meaning they may have been forced to stay in or return to abusive environments. Local organizations that serve these victims and their families say that emergency shelter requests have increased, while funding for these critical services has decreased or been diverted to other programs. Last week, I helped introduced a bipartisan bill to address this problem by leveling the playing field for transitional housing and encouraging HUD to find living options that best support survivors, so that they can receive the housing, safety, and trauma support they need to begin the healing and recovery process. Watch this WDAZ story to learn more about how my bill would help provide urgently needed shelter.

For so many of us, this is a time of year to reflect on our many blessings and our hopes for the upcoming year. Merry Christmas to everyone in North Dakota and across the country, as well as to those spending time away from their loved ones this holiday season as they protect our nation both at home and abroad.

Last night I voted to avoid a government shutdown. But lurching from deadline to deadline is no way to govern, and it’s unfortunate that Congress is once again kicking the can down the road for another few weeks. North Dakota families and small businesses understand the importance of budgeting and planning for their year ahead because they need to make sure they can put food on the table and support their kids, so there’s no excuse for Congress’s failure to do the same.   I’m disappointed that the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) was only extended for three months. That’s little consolation to families with sick children who rely on the program for their health care needs. This program is about life and death, and the families who rely on it need long-term certainty to know that their kids will be protected.  This bill waived the PAYGO law, meaning that vital programs like Medicare and agricultural assistance are not cut. Avoiding cuts is good, but it means Congress is still adding a $1.5 trillion tax bill to our nation’s credit card, to be paid for by our children and grandchildren. And experts and academics have said the Republican tax bill won’t pay for itself. Unfortunately, the options aren’t good – either cut critical programs families rely on or push huge costs onto future generations. North Dakotans expect and deserve more fiscal responsibility than that. Since before joining the U.S. Senate, I’ve called for Congress to pass a balanced budget amendment, and I cosponsored a bill to do just that because the federal government needs to gets its fiscal house in order.  While Congress avoided a government shutdown, which would be damaging to our economy and disruptive to many North Dakotans, it must end this cycle of short-term spending bills that just kick the can down the road, and instead give our economy the certainty it needs to grow.

While rents in the Minot area have decreased somewhat from record highs, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's funding formula to help families afford homes has been far too slow to reflect conditions on the ground. After I urged the Department to recognize shifting housing costs around Minot, HUD approved the Minot Housing Authority’s waiver request to adjust their fair market payment standards, which will give more Minot residents access to affordable housing. To learn more, read this Minot Daily News editorial on how local and federal officials are working to find ways to make housing more affordable in our state.

An accurate census is absolutely essential to making sure North Dakota’s communities are represented and get the resources they need to thrive. But a top government watchdog is warning that the 2020 census is at risk, partly due to lack of leadership. The top two Census Bureau positions are vacant at a critical time for the next census, so I joined with Senator Tom Carper to urge the administration to nominate qualified candidates without delay. With so much on the line for North Dakota – especially our rural communities and those living in Indian Country – we need strong and accountable leadership guiding the census.

North Dakota’s farmers have faced challenges with the ARC-CO program for years. It’s a program that helps farmers get through difficult times like droughts, so it’s critically important that we fix it in the next Farm Bill. That’s why in October, I introduced a bipartisan plan to address the concerns I’m hearing from farmers across the state to improve and strengthen the program and keep our agriculture industry strong.
